The accountable MPs are the peoples representatives elected by\nprocess of voting .<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Indian democracy cannot\nbe snuffed by the Supreme Court --&nbsp; like in the case below about NJAC .&nbsp; This is a direct affront to the democracy and democratic process.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">CHECK OUT THE TRAVESTY\nOF JUSTICE BELOW\u2014&nbsp; INDIA IS INDEED A KOSHER BANANA REPUBLIC .. &nbsp; &nbsp;JEW ROTHSCHILD STILL RULES INDIA..<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">National Judicial\nAppointments Commission (NJAC) was a proposed body which would have been\nresponsible for the appointment and transfer of judges to the higher judiciary\nin India.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Commission was established by amending the Constitution of India\nthrough the ninety-ninth constitution amendment with the Constitution\n(Ninety-Ninth Amendment) Act, 2014 or 99th Constitutional Amendment Act-2014\npassed by the Lok Sabha on 13 August 2014 and by the Rajya Sabha on 14 August\n2014.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The NJAC would have replaced the\ncollegium system for the appointment of judges as invoked by the Supreme court\nvia judicial fiat by a new system.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Along with the Constitution Amendment Act,\nthe National Judicial Appointments Commission Act, 2014, was also passed by the\nParliament of India to regulate the functions of the National Judicial Appointments\nCommission. &nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The NJAC Bill and the\nConstitutional Amendment Bill, was ratified by 16 of the state legislatures in\nIndia, and subsequently assented by the President of India Pranab Mukherjee on\n31 December 2014.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The NJAC Act and the\nConstitutional Amendment Act came into force from 13 April 2015. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">On 16 October 2015, the\nConstitution Bench of Supreme Court by 4:1 Majority upheld the collegium system\nand struck down the NJAC as unconstitutional after hearing the petitions filed\nby several persons and bodies with Supreme Court Advocates on Record\nAssociation (SCAoRA) being the first and lead petitioner.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Justices J.\nS. Khehar, Madan Lokur, Kurian Joseph and Adarsh Kumar Goel had declared the\n99th Amendment and NJAC Act unconstitutional while Justice Chelameswar upheld\nit.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-8TQ_r-LQI64/W9-xzVvBVQI/AAAAAAABe04/SutOQh1uEeYNl-M49PeP_6lg0g58OsRDACLcBGAs/s1600/coveEr2_102315075133.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2014/05/interlinking-rivers-of-india-capt-ajit.html\" style=\"background-color: lime;\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2014/05/interlinking-rivers-of-india-capt-ajit.html</a><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The doctrine of\nJudicial Review was laid down by the United States Supreme Court in the\ncelebrated case of Marbury vs Madison 5 US (1 Cranch) 137 (1803), in which the\n<b style=\"background-color: white;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">DEEP STATE CONTROLLED </span></b>court held that the Judiciary has the power to review\nactions of the Legislature or the Executive in order to ensure that the\nexercise of such power is not in violation of the Constitution.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This has been\ntranslated to India, despite Indian constitution being a straight lift of the\nBritish constitution.. The British constitution is just a bunch of loose\nsheaths of paper.. The British Parliament is supreme.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: white; font-size: large;\"><span style=\"color: purple;\">Ex-CJI Dipak Misra\nspAke.. \u201c The Supreme Court can strike down any Act of Parliament if the Court\nfinds that the Act is unconstitutional&nbsp;&nbsp; </span><b><span style=\"color: red;\">This\nis nonsense </span></b><span style=\"color: purple;\">as the Indian Parliament can amend the constitution any time they\nwant.. &nbsp;&nbsp;India is a democracy\u2014not a\ndictator ship run by DEEP STATE PAYRoLL judges , as the case was in USA, &nbsp;till Donald Trump became president</span></span><span style=\"font-size: 12pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">No doubt, it is the\nright of a citizen to approach the court and question the constitutional\nvalidity of a particular law enacted by the Legislature. However, merely\nbecause a section of persons &nbsp;( say a few\npeople will prick sans balls &nbsp;and twat ) opposes\nthe law, would not mean that it has become a separate class by itself..&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">There\nis something called the majority, which rules in a democracy.. font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\">\n\n\n\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2018/05/discretion-subjective-objective-value.html\" style=\"background-color: lime;\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2018/05/discretion-subjective-objective-value.html</a><o:p></o:p></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"></span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">There is a conspiracy\nfrom desh drohi forces in the payroll of foreign forces t hijack the system.\nThee ease with which anyone can file a PIL is one reason for its proliferation\nand misuse. &nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Even letters written to the\ncourts or some facebook comments are entertained as public interest litigation.\n&nbsp;&nbsp;Some cases are initiated suo motu (on\ntheir own).&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The charge of a nominal fee of Rs 50 in the Supreme Court is\nanother contributory factor. Also, PIL cases are seldom dismissed summarily,\nunlike many civil and criminal appeals. This too encourages litigants,<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Article 32 is not to be\ninvoked for infringement of a personal right of contract, nor is to be invoked\nfor agitating questions which are capable of disposal under special enactments<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A writ petition cannot\nbe filed under Article 32 to enforce right under Article 265 of the\nConstitution, as the right conferred by Article 265 is not a right conferred by\nPart III of the Constitution.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In the hands of the\nSupreme Court public interest litigation in India has taken multidimensional\ncharacter.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">The age-old adversarial system has been given a go-by.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">With the\nadvent of judicial activism, letters, newspaper reports, complaints by\nnon-aggrieved FAALTHU public-spirited persons ( like DEEP STATE agent Prashant Bhushan with\na&nbsp; vested agenda , always ) , social\naction groups bringing to the notice of the Court regarding violation of\nfundamental rights were dealt with treating them as writ petitions and the\nrelief of compensation was also granted through writ jurisdiction under Article\n32 of the Constitution.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"color: purple; font-size: large;\">Supremacy of the\nConstitution is a doctrine where by the Constitution is the supreme law of the\nland and all the State organs including Parliament and State Legislatures are\nbound by it. They must act within the limits laid down by the Constitution. <o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; color: purple; font-size: large;\">But we the people will\ndecide on the limits ( in consonance with our culture and times ) using our\nelected accountable law makers ..We don\u2019t have a nationwide referendum system\nin India ..&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-size: 14pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\">&nbsp;<span style=\"color: blue;\">The Constitution can be amended by the Parliament\n\u2013 which can alter or modify many of the laws of the Constitution by a simple\nmajority &nbsp;as is required for ordinary legislations.&nbsp;</span></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"color: blue; font-size: large;\">Parliament can amend other major parts of the Constitution with special\nmajority (a majority of not less than 2/3 of the members of each House present &nbsp;and majority of them voting) as mentioned in\nArticle 368.<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"color: blue; font-size: large;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"color: blue; font-size: large;\">The amendments to\ncertain features affecting the federal structure of Indian State requires\nspecial majority with ratification by half of the States.&nbsp;</span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"color: blue; font-size: large;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"color: blue; font-size: large;\">Provisions related to\nelection to the President and its manner; extent of the executive power of the\nUnion and the states; Supreme Court and high courts etc. fall under this.<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"color: blue; font-size: large;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"color: blue; font-size: large;\">The Parliament can also\nmodify the constitutional provisions by supplementing them with its own laws.<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"color: blue; font-size: large;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"color: blue; font-size: large;\">As of January 2018,\nthere have been 123 Amendment Bills and 101 Amendment acts to the Constitution\nof India since it was first enacted in 1950.&nbsp;</span></span><br />\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"color: blue; font-size: large;\"><br /></span></span>\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"color: blue; font-size: large;\">The US constitution is rigid and\nthat is why it has been amended only 33 times so far-- because the kosher DEEP STATE controls the US judiciary&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"color: blue; font-size: large;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\"><span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-size: large;\">The Constitutional\nAmendment Acts like the First, Fourth, Twenty Fourth, Twenty Fifth, Thirty\nNinth, Forty-second, Forty-fourth, Seventy-third, Seventy-fourth and\nNinety-seventh are vital changes so far included in the original Constitution.</span><span style=\"font-size: 14pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></span></div>\n<span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_amendments_of_the_Constitution_of_India\" style=\"background-color: lime;\">https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_amendments_of_the_Constitution_of_India</a><o:p></o:p></div>\n<span style=\"color: blue;\"></span>\n<span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"background-color: cyan;\">Judicial review is not\nspecifically mentioned in the Constitution of India; the concept is borrowed from\nthe United States Constitution, which is NONSENSE !&nbsp;</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Article 32 in The\nConstitution Of India 1949<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">32. Remedies for\nenforcement of rights conferred by this Part<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">(1) The right to move\nthe Supreme Court by appropriate proceedings for the enforcement of the rights\nconferred by this Part is guaranteed<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">(2) The Supreme Court\nshall have power to issue directions or orders or writs, including writs in the\nnature of habeas corpus, mandamus, prohibition, quo warranto and certiorari,\nwhichever may be appropriate, for the enforcement of any of the rights\nconferred by this Part<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">(3) Without prejudice\nto the powers conferred on the Supreme Court by clause ( 1 ) and ( 2 ),\nParliament may by law empower any other court to exercise within the local\nlimits of its jurisdiction all or any of the powers exercisable by the Supreme\nCourt under clause ( 2 )</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">(4) The right\nguaranteed by this article shall not be suspended except as otherwise provided\nfor by this Constitution<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Article 32:</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Allows any <b style=\"background-color: white;\">AGGRIEVED</b> &nbsp;person to knock on the doors of the Supreme\nCourt in case of (what according to him &nbsp;is) a violation of Fundamental Rights.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Empowers the SC to\nissue Writs to enforce such person's Fundamental Rights, if such a violation\nhas indeed taken place.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"color: purple;\">IN THE CASE OF\nSABARIMALA THE PIL WAS FILED BY A CRYPTO JEW MUSLIM NAMED NAUSHAD KHAN.. HE WAS\nNOT AN AGGRIEVED PERSON.. &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;KHAN BABY SHOULD HAVE WORRIED ABOUT MUSLIM\nWOMEN NOT BEING ALLOWED IN SUNNI MOSQUES.<o:p></o:p></span></span><br />\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"background-color: white;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">WE ASK THE MODI GOVT TO\nPASS A LAW CREATING STRICT GUIDELINES FOR JUDICIARY TO ENTERTAIN PILs.. &nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"background-color: white;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"background-color: white;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">NO FOREIGN FUNDED NGO MUST BE ALLOWED TO FILE\nA PIL..&nbsp;</span></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"background-color: white;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"background-color: white;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">IF A PIL HAS ULTERIOR MOTIVE OR IS FRIVOLOUS, THE PARTY WHO FILED THE\nPIL MUST BE FINED HEAVILY AND BE BARRED FROM FILING A PIL EVER AGAIN.</span></span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Public Interest\nLitigation ('PIL') has undergone evolutionary changes in terms of its\nperception, ambit, accessibility and implications. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Supreme Court advocate\nAman Hingorani\u2019 s mother Kapila Hingorani had filed the first PIL (Hussainara\nKhatoon vs State of Bihar) in India in 1979 that highlighted the plight of\nundertrials languishing in Bihar\u2019s jails<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nothing much has\nhappened after 4 decades . Undertrials are poor people who rot in jail because\nthey don\u2019t have the money to pay for bail and someone to stand surety showing\nso many documents to the judge. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">What started as a\njuristic revolution of the eighties for poorer sections to have easy access to\njustice delivery system has evolved itself into a multi dimensional judicial\nmechanism, encompassing almost every aspect of our day-to-day life - consumer\nwelfare, ecology, environment, forests, public accountability, public welfare\nschemes, illegal immigration, national heritage protection and so on and so\nforth.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Instances are not\nwanting when PIL and RTI mechanisms are misused, inter alia, to target\npolitical rivals, hassle public authorities and settle personal scores.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Courts, while dealing\nwith PILs, are certainly aware of the increasing thinning line between justice\ndelivery and possible encroachment on executive and legislative domains and\nhence, the Supreme Court's strict guidelines on substance and procedure for\nentertaining PILs.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\">While reading the\njudgment, Chief Justice Dipak Misra said, \"Adultery cannot be a criminal\noffence, however it can be a ground for civil issues like divorce\"<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; , serif; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow; color: red; font-size: x-large;\"><b>Hey Melord will you pay\nthe fuckin' alimony ?</b></span><span style=\"font-size: 14pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Once a law is enacted\nand included in the Ninth Schedule, it gets protection under Article 31-B\n(validation of certain Acts and Regulations) and is not subject to judicial\nscrutiny.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Ninth Schedule\n(Article 31-B) was introduced by the former Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru to\nkeep certain laws particularly those on land reforms beyond the scope of\njudicial review. Over the years 284 laws were included in it<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Ninth Schedule includes\nthe accession of Sikkim with India.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The first amendment to\nthe Indian Constitution added the Ninth Schedule to it. It was introduced by\nthe Nehru Government, on 10 May 1951 to address judicial decisions and\npronouncements espe\u00adcially about the chapter on fundamental rights.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nehru was\nalso very clear on the purpose behind the first amendment. The state wanted to\npursue nationalisation, take away lands from the zamindars, re-distribute them,\nand make special provisions for the socially and economically backward.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Due to the adoption of\nthe Thirty-eighth Amendment, the Supreme Court was not allowed to preside over\nany laws adopted during a state of emergency which infringe fundamental rights\nunder article 32 (the right to constitutional remedies).</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Forty-second\nAmendment widened Article 31C and added Articles 368(4) and 368(5), stating\nthat any law passed by Parliament could not be challenged in court.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\">In a landmark ruling on\n11 January 2007, the Supreme Court of India ruled that all laws (including\nthose in the Ninth Schedule) would be open to Judicial Review if they violated\nthe basic structure of the constitution.&nbsp;</span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white;
