, &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">He who has no faith in\nhimself can never have faith in God.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Shraddha hrudayya\nyakutyaa shradhayaa vindate vasu. --(<b>Rig Veda 10/151/4) 5000 BC</b>.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Meaning:&nbsp;&nbsp; Shraddha (faith) is the symbol of the high\nsentiment of the heart.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Shraddha cannot be\naptly translated into English.&nbsp;&nbsp; Loosely\nput, it may be be called faith / trust.&nbsp;&nbsp;\n<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In the context of\nVedanta it is the trust that one has in Veda ( sruti ) , where the Veda is\ntaken to be a valid means of knowledge(pramana).&nbsp;&nbsp; It is the deep trust that the Veda is a\nmeans to knowledge, hence a means for liberation.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Vedas are timeless and\napaurusheya (not a fabrication of human mind).&nbsp;&nbsp;\nThey are eternal and are revealed to mankind by seers (\nmaharishis).&nbsp;&nbsp; This vedic wisdom has\nprovided many with knowledge. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The spiritual stalwarts\nare living examples for us as a proof for the validity of the vedas.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Single messiah , single\nholy book religions cry \u201cGod is there to save you\u201d, \u201cYou have sinned and need a\nsaviour\u201d etc; under such contexts a blind faith props up.&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">You believe in the\nsaviour thinking that you have sinned.&nbsp;\nYou are doomed if you do not believe the saviour.&nbsp;&nbsp; That will be YET YENOTHER&nbsp; sin !<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Vedanta says you need\nnot be saved at all. You alone are the truth, the non dual truth. There is no\nrescue work needed!&nbsp; Where is the\nquestion of blind faith, when all that is needed is knowledge. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Liberation for us is\nthrough knowledge, and here, there is no role for blind faith to play.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A Hindu is allowed to\nquestion and discuss; but the attitude matters.&nbsp;&nbsp; If one questions with the idea of throwing\nshit on Veda, then it is lack of shraddha (ashraddha).&nbsp;&nbsp; Instead if one says, veda cannot be wrong,\nbut there is some confusion in my understanding and the concept of me being the\nwhole, the truth, is not sinking; then it is shraddha.&nbsp; The person has doubts, conviction is not\nthere, but he has trust in the veda as being a valid means of knowledge.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Many of our Upanishads\nare in the form of dialogue between guru and disciple.&nbsp; The student asks questions till he gains conviction.&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Neither the guru nor\nthe upanishad expects you to listen once, blindly accept and pack up.&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">There is a gradual\nunfolding of Vedanta by an adept guru. The whole learning environment is open,\ngraceful,&nbsp; friendly, encouraging, logical\nand of course filled with shraddha.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">SHRADDA WAS REPLACED BY\nBHAKTI&nbsp; (BLIND DEVOTION ) AND SANATANA\nDHARMA WAS HIJACKED BY JEW ROTHSCHILD ..&nbsp;\n<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">AT EVERY DESH DROHI\nLITERARY FEST,&nbsp;&nbsp; A HUGE CHUNK OF TIME IS\nLEFT ASIDE FOR THE FAKE AND BACKDATED CREATIONS OF ROTHSCHILDs BHAKTI MOVEMENT <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">FROM NOW ON I ASK MY\nREADERS TO WATCH THESE FOREIGN FUNDED DROHIS <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Shraddha is the first step in one's search\nfor God.&nbsp; In the fourth chapter of the\nBhagavad Gita, Sri Krishna says, \"shraddhavan labhate jnanam, one with\nshraddha gains knowledge.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Thus shraddha is like a\nstepping stone; with the help of a teacher, believe in God eventually leads to\ndirect knowledge.&nbsp;&nbsp; Shraddha is\nindispensable, because without it, knowledge of the Lord will forever be beyond\nones grasp.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Check out the FAKE\nBhakti movement heroes-- 12 Alvars , 63 Nayanars, Andal, Basava, Bhagat Pipa,\nAllama Prabhu, Akka Mahadevi, Kabir, Tulsidas, Kabirdas, Kalidas, Ramdas,\nChandidas , Surdas , Ravidas, Gusainji, Ghananand, Ramananda&nbsp; Sripadaraja, Vyasatirtha, Purandara Dasa,\nKanakadasa, Vijaya Dasa, Six goswamis of Vrindavan , Raskhan, Jayadeva Goswami,\nNamdev, Eknath, Tukaram, Mirabai, Ramprasad Sen, Sankardev, Vallabha Acharya,\nNarsinh Mehta, Gangasati,Chaitanya Mahaprabhu etc etc<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">EVEN ADI SHANKARACHARYA\nWAS CONVERTED TO A BHAKTI CHARACTER</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">THIS FOUL AND CUNNING\nSUBSTITUTION OF SHRADDHA WITH BHAKTI, IN THE WARP AND WEFT OF HINDUISM BY JEW\nROTHSCHILD REDUCED&nbsp; THE GREAT\nSPIRITUALITY OF SANATANA DHARMA TO THE ABSURD LEVEL OF SINGLE HOLY BOOK/ SINGLE\nMESSIAH RELIGIONS ..<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sabda-pramana as a\nconcept which means reliable expert testimony. The schools of Hinduism which\nconsider it epistemically valid suggest that a human being needs to know\nnumerous facts, and with the limited time and energy available, he can learn\nonly a fraction of those facts and truths directly.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In order for one to\ngive their assent to a worldview that renders to language the cosmic and\nsalvific roles Bhartrihari does, a theory that posits that language is the\nmedium of ultimate knowledge, one must be convinced that language in general\nhas the capacity to yield ordinary knowledge.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Given the way Bhartrihari\nconceptualizes language, as not primarily referent directed, but instead as referent-constructing,\nwe need to look at how the grammarian thematizes the knowledge-conferring power\nof language within his own peculiarly unique framework.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sphota may be\ncharacterized as the intersubjective, universal \"store-house\" of\nmeaning, the ground of all linguistic activity and communication. Sphota is the\nunifying principle that connects the word, the grammatical form of the word,\nand the meaning. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Furthermore, just as\nwords and sentences represent \u201cpieces\u201d of the meaning extracted from the whole,\nthe objects and states of affairs these pieces represent actually refer to a\n\u201cwhole of objects meant\u201d or an entire reality.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In classical Indian\nthought, objects are thought to be constituted of substance (dravya), but in\nBhartrihari , substance can be distinguished into two kinds, the substance of\nall things, which is Brahman, and the other individual, empirical substances.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The empirical notion of substance here may be derived from the grammatical\noperation of ekashesha, explained by Panini as using individual word-tokens to\nrefer to individual objects-substances.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Thus, names or singular terms are said\nby the earliest grammarians to refer to one substance at a time, therefore\nsubstance is defined through the relation of reference, and the nature of each\nsubstance is so specific that we cannot posit any general properties possessed\nby all of them. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhartrihari defines\n\"actual\" or empirical substance as that which we refer to by using\nindexicals and quantifiers, which refer to anything in our ontological reality:\n'this' \u2018that\u2019 \u2018something\u2019 or \u2018anything.\u2019&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The term \u2018this\u2019 points out an\nexistence given to perception, while \u2018that\u2019 refers to something whose existence\ncan be validated by some other means of knowledge but which is not available to\nperception. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhartrihari &nbsp;acknowledges the pragmatic and common sense\nview of \u201csubstance\u201d as \u201ca relative concept being dependent on our concept of\nquality (guna). A substance is that which is said to be distinguished and a\nquality is that which distinguishes the substance.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhartrihari's\ncontribution to this debate changes the very notion of substance into a much\nmore inclusive and general concept, since anything we refer to using a name or\nsubstantive term, even generic properties and verbs, become substances in that\nthey are distinguished by words<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In the third book of\nthe Vakyapadiya, Bhartrhari defines the concept of \u2018quality\u2019/guna as dependent\nupon, as arising from substance. . For him, qualities, existing in relation to\nsubstances serve to further differentiate those substances by \u201cdelimiting their\nscope.\u201d <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhartrihari's\ncontribution of his particular theory of the \"imaginative\nconstruction\" of perceptions and language once again emerges within the\ncontext of debates with competing theories of knowledge. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhartrihari\u2019s theory\nposits knowledge as a matter of specifically linguistic construction. The\nconcept of vikalpa for him implies the following: the structure of language\nshapes how we categorize the objects of our experience and our descriptions of\nreality as a whole.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Even at the most immediate levels of awareness), we must\nconceptualize and therefore interpret the contents of sense perception. Thus,\nat the level of pure sensation, the sensory core is already saturated, as it\nwere, with the \u201cdeep structure\u201d of language.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhartrihari, as an ontological\nmonist, does not distinguish between a pure perception and a constructed perception\nsuch that the former is concept-free and ineffable and the latter\nconcept-loaded and autonomously constructed, because he thinks that perception\nis inherently verbal.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Not only are sense data and linguistic units\nnon-different, but they are expressive of the unitary principle of\nBrahman-which is differentiated into the plurality of linguistic objects that\nmake up the world.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhartrihari &nbsp;says that the act of perception, rather than\nacquiring linguistic clothing after the bare particular has already been\npresented to consciousness, can only be aware of the object before it as a\n'this\u2019 or \u2018that\u2019, that is, as an awareness of something only as a particular\nand as such, identifiable<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">For Bhartrihari, the\nword makes the thing an individual, and as one moves further and further along\nthe refined categories of what is conventionally known as denotation, the word\nmakes the thing what it is.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">For Bhartrihari, the difference the Logicians posit\nbetween the ontological and the linguistic would make meanings of all kinds,\nmundane ones and religious ones, contingent on the circumstances and speaker.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">But if perception is innately verbal, no perilous bridge need be suspended over\nsome supposed abyss between vision and truth, both in our mundane lives and for\nthe Maharishis who pronounced the Vedas.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The word then makes the thing, and\nBrahman makes the world, and so it is entirely proper to speak of words as the\ncreator of all things (shabda-Brahman).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The shallow Western\nmind cannot fathom the depth of Bharthari\u2019s intellect.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">His explorations into\nthe relations between language, thought and reality reflect contemporary\nphilosophical concerns with meaning, language use, and communication,\nparticularly in the work of thieves Chomsky, Wittgenstein, Grice, and Austin. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Noam Chomsky has lifted\nhis entire works from ancient Indian Grammar.&nbsp;\nHis works are useless as he lifted without understanding from a perfect divine\nlanguage Sanskrit for application to a ridiculous language of syntax called\nEnglish.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The grammar of the Sanskrit language has a complex but perfect verbal\nsystem, rich nominal declension, and extensive use of compound nouns. Sanskrit\nhas ten classes of verbs divided into two broad groups: athematic and thematic.\nThe thematic verbs are so called because an a, called the theme vowel, is\ninserted between the stem and the ending.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This serves to make the thematic\nverbs generally more regular. Exponents used in verb conjugation include\nprefixes, suffixes, infixes, and reduplication. Every root has (not necessarily\nall distinct) zero, gu\u1e47a, and v\u1e5bddhi grades.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Because of Sanskrit's\ncomplex declension system, the word order is free. In usage, there is a strong\ntendency toward subject \u2013 object \u2013 verb (SOV), which was the original system in\nplace in Vedic prose. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">S is the subject, V is\nthe verb and O is the object; the three exhaustive elements of a simple\nsentence.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Malayalam is\nsubject\u2013object\u2013verb (SOV) language is one in which the subject, object, and\nverb of a sentence appear or usually appear in that order. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">If English were SOV,\n\" Dick apple ate\" would be an ordinary sentence, as opposed to the\nactual Standard English \" Dick ate apple\". Hindi is SOV.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Hebrew is\nsubject\u2013verb\u2013object (SVO) is a sentence structure where the subject comes\nfirst, the verb second, and the object third. English is SVO.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">BILBLICAL HEBREW WAS\nVSO LIKE CLASSICAL ARABIC .<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">SANSKRIT IS THE MOTHER\nOF ALL LANGUAGES<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Simple sentences in\nSanskrit do not need to follow any specified structure. They are attached\neither to the subject or the object in form of \u2018vibhakti\u2019. Thus, in principle,\nevery simple sentence in Sanskrit can be condensed into three distinct words:\nthe subject, the verb and the object. We can write these three words in any\norder we want (all 3! = 6 ways) and the sentence will bear the same meaning. A\nunique meaning. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sanskrit like Malayalam\nis usually used in SOV format though.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sanskrit's grammatical\nstructure, words carry extra information with them. Because of this extra\ninformation, word order is more flexible in Sanskrit than in English.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">IN STUPID ENGLISH\nBANANA CAN EAT ELEPHANT, WHICH CANNOT HAPPEN IN SANSKRIT.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sanskrit, uses\ninflection to a great extent. In Sanskrit, a complex idea can exist as one word\nand still carry a single and precise meaning.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Malayalam and Hindi employs\npostpositions, whereas English employs prepositions<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Term/Definition<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Grammar/The set of\nrules that describes or defines a language<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Grammatical/used to\ndescribe an expression that follows the rules of grammar.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Subject/ In a sentence,\nthe thing that performs an action<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Verb/ In a sentence,\nthe word that describes the action<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Object/ In a sentence,\nthe thing that is affected by the action<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Emphasis/ a quality\nthat tells us to pay attention to certain words<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Inflection/ the act of\nchanging a word to further clarify its meaning<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Thief Noam Chomsky showed\nthat syntax is independent from phonology and semantics. This led to major\nadvances in linguistics but the analysis continued to be phrased in terms of\nrules..<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Then Chomsky made\nanother radical change- he showed that the formal properties of syntax may be\nderived from more abstract principles.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Jew Noam Chomsky, is\ncalled the the greatest linguist since Panini\u2014BALLS ! &nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">He lifted everything halfbaked from Sanskrit\nGrammar. Panini's work is purely grammatical and lexicographic, cultural and\ngeographical inferences can be drawn from the vocabulary he uses in examples.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Predecessors of Noam Chomsky\nwere all Sanskrit scholars\u2014Today they admit \u201cNone of us drink from wells that\nwe have dug and Chomsky is no exception\u201d.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">There is a baggage of\nsources that&nbsp; each scholar carries that\noriginates years, decades, centuries, even millennia before. It is a composite\nof prooftext&nbsp; sources that receives\noccasionally a side reference in a footnote or short comment, but which\nindicates the&nbsp; philosophical stream that\nthe writer or scholar is tapping for inspiration. . &nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Thief Noam Chomsky has admitted that great\nancient Indian Sanskrit &nbsp;grammarians &nbsp;contributed to his inspiration( sic ). His Jew\ngot inspired after stealing?<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">All the \u201cgreat\u201d spirits\nthat he cites as his pioneers all had one thing in common: they studied\nSanskrit and admired Panini the Hindu grammarian. And this is where this article\noriginated. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u201cAnyone who has but\njust a glimpse of understanding of Hindu philosophy and religion will&nbsp; know that this pantheistic religion views all\nthe sounds of language as gods. The gods are eternal and thus&nbsp; language in a person has an eternal ring to\nit in us&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Panini left his gurukula and\nwent far&nbsp; away into the Himalayas to do\nsevere Tapas &nbsp;to please Lord Siva.\nSatisfied with his austere penance, Lord&nbsp;\nShiva emerged before him and granted him the bonus of extreme intellect.\n&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\">Shiva then danced his Tandav in his\necstasy and gave birth to fourteen holy Sutras Aphorism by beating his drum ( Damaru\n) fourteen times.&nbsp;</span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\">Blessed with astuteness, Panini accepted them and returned\nhome.&nbsp;</span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/3B6-u8c7Xp8/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/3B6-u8c7Xp8?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Then he composed a grammar of Sanskrit language which became the first\nand the most perfect grammar that could ever be composed. There has been NO\nchanges in Panini\u2019s Grammar for the past 7500 years.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Dimirti Mendeleyev modeled\nhis Periodic Tables after Panini\u2019s 54 Sanskrit alphabets &nbsp;.It just shows that Sanskrit is a divine\nlanguage. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2016/12/108-numerical-equivalent-of-hindu-king.html\" style=\"background-color: lime;\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2016/12/108-numerical-equivalent-of-hindu-king.html</a><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/wXkaA8icQu4/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/wXkaA8icQu4?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Noam Chomsky's concept\nof \"deep structure\" and \"surface structure\" was lifted from\nBhartrhari. Deep structure and surface structure (also D-structure and\nS-structure, although these abbreviated forms are sometimes used with distinct\nmeanings) are concepts used in linguistics, specifically in the study of syntax\nin the Chomskyan tradition of transformational generative grammar.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The deep\nstructure gives the semantic component of a sentence, while the surface\nstructure gives the proper phonological information to express that thought.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Chomsky coined and\npopularized the terms \"deep structure\" and \"surface\nstructure\" in the early 1960s. Chomsky&nbsp;\nDID NOT BORROW&nbsp; from Hockett as\nwritten by the white man --- thief Chomsky lifted it from Bhartrhari..&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Chomsky\nfirst referred to these concepts in his 1962 paper The Logical Basis of\nLinguistic Theory (later published as Current Issues in Linguistic Theory in\n1964).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">There is no such thing\nas a language without grammar.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Vedic srutis had\ndivine Math embedded ..and precision Sanskrit Grammar was developed on those\nlines.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: cyan; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><b>MERU, PASCALSs TRIANGLE\n, SIERPINSKI TRIANGLE, GOLDEN MEAN, FIBONACCI SERIES , LUCAS NUMBER, ULAM\nSPIRAL , ISOTOPE MAGIC ARE ALL EMBEDDED IN VEDIC SRUTIS<o:p></o:p></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bharthari\u2019s theory of\nlanguage recognizes that meaning is conveyed in formalist terms where meaning\nis organized along syntactical rules.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">But it makes the leap, not made by modern\nWestern philosophers, that such a view of language does not merely serve our\nmundane communicative purposes and see to the achievement of practical goals,\nbut leads to paramount metaphysical knowledge, a knowledge carrying with it a\npalpable salvific value.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">CHECK OUT HOW THE\nIMMORAL WHITE MAN HAS BEEN RUNNING DOWN SANSKRIT, THE OLDEST LANGUAGE ON THIS\nPLANET.. &nbsp;&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-size: large;\"><b>THERE ARE NO SYNONYMS\nIN SANSKRIT.&nbsp; &nbsp;THE MONEIR WILLIAMS DICTIONARY HAS ONLY 40% OF SANSKRIT\nVOCABULARY..</b></span><span style=\"font-size: 12pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">The </span><b><span style=\"color: red;\">LIAR Daniel H. H.\nIngalls Sr.</span></b><span style=\"color: blue;\">Professor of Sanskrit at Harvard University gives the below BULLSHIT\u2014 nay\nWHITE KOSHER LIE ..&nbsp;</span></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue; font-size: large;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">This </span><b><span style=\"color: red;\">BASTARD</span></b><span style=\"color: blue;\"> studied Sanskrit in India to inject poison in\nour ancient scriptures..&nbsp;</span></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue; font-size: large;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: white; font-size: large;\"><b><span style=\"color: red;\">Lying JEWESS Wendy Doniger</span></b><span style=\"color: blue;\"> is his student..</span></span><span style=\"font-size: 12pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">QUOTE: Peculiar\ncharacteristics -In the introduction to his celebrated translation of\nVidyakara's 'Subhashitaratnakosha', Daniel H.H. Ingalls describes some peculiar\ncharacteristics of the Sanskrit language. He refers to the enormous vocabulary\nof Sanskrit, and also of the presence of a larger choice of <span style=\"background-color: white;\">SYNONYMS IN\nSANSKRIT </span>than any other language he knew of. Further, he writes, just as there\nexist a <span style=\"background-color: white;\">VAST NUMBER OF SYNONYMS</span> for almost any word in Sanskrit, there also\nexist synonymous constructions. Ingalls writes that in elementary Sanskrit\nexaminations he would ask his students to write in Sanskrit the sentence 'You\nmust fetch the horse' in ten different ways. Actually, Ingalls explains, it is\npossible to write the sentence in Sanskrit in around fifteen different ways 'by\nusing active or passive constructions, imperative or optative, an auxiliary\nverb, or any of the three gerundive forms, each of which, by the way, gives a\ndifferent metrical pattern'. Ingalls emphasizes that while these constructions\ndiffer formally, emotionally they are identical and completely interchangeable.\nHe comments that in any natural language this would be impossible. Ingalls uses\nthis and other arguments<span style=\"background-color: white;\"> TO SHOW THAT SANSKRIT IS NOT A NATURAL LANGUAGE BUT AN\nARTIFICIAL LANGUAGE</span> . By 'artificial', he explains he means it was learned\nafter some other Indian language had been learned by simple conditioning. ( <span style=\"background-color: white;\">HEY\nWAS THAT TAMIL\u2014YOU CUNT ?</span> ). Ingalls writes: 'Every Indian, one may suppose,\ngrew up learning naturally the language of his mother and his playmates. Only\nafter this and if he belonged to the priesthood or the nobility or to such a\nprofessional caste as that of the clerks, the physicians, or the astrologers\nwould he learn Sanskrit. As a general rule, Sanskrit was not the language of\nthe family. It furnished no subconscious symbols for the impressions which we\nreceive in childhood nor for the emotions which form our character in early\nadolescence.'[22]<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sanskrit_grammar\" style=\"background-color: lime;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\">https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sanskrit_grammar</span></a><span style=\"font-size: 12pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\"><b>SANSKRIT IS A VERY\nPRECISE LANGUAGE \u2013ONE WORD ,ONE MEANING<o:p></o:p></b></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\"><b><br /></b></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\"><b><br /></b></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\"><b>THERE ARE NO SYNONYMS\nIN SANSKRIT\u2014LIKE THE STUPID LANGUAGE ENGLISH.<o:p></o:p></b></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\"><b><br /></b></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\"><b>BY INTRODUCING FAKE\nSYNONYMS IN SANSKRIT,&nbsp; THE BASTARD WHITE\nINVADER <o:p></o:p></b></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\"><b>---- &nbsp;MADE OUR VEDAS LOOK LIKE MINDLESS MONKEY\nCHATTER<o:p></o:p></b></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\"><b>----&nbsp; PLACED MONKEY HANUMAN ON KRISHNAs CHARIOT\nFLAG INSTEAD OF GARUDA<o:p></o:p></b></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow;
