, &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n(sha)&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0937</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; (sha) ,&nbsp;\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0938</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n(sh)&nbsp; and </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0939</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n(ha ).</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Such unique\norganization of the alphabet underlines the attention paid to the patterns of\narticulated sound; points&nbsp; of its\nlocation; and , to degree of resonance,&nbsp;\nin a way that has not been attempted in any other language\u2014though every\nlanguage on this planet has lifted from Sanskrit<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<ol id=\"bc_0_82TB\" style=\"background-color: #cccccc; font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, Times, FreeSerif, serif; font-size: 16px; list-style-type: none; padding: 0px;\">\n<li class=\"comment\" id=\"bc_0_81B\" kind=\"b\" style=\"border-bottom: 0px; margin: 0px 0px 16px; padding: 0.25em 0px 0px;\"><div class=\"avatar-image-container\" style=\"float: left; margin: 0.2em 0px 0px; max-height: 36px; overflow: hidden; width: 36px;\">\n<img src=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-0Gvy5mBcipE/WlAJZNfU3zI/AAAAAAABXsU/wZaBJr4cOoclmnshY0dz6Y3NbokDpLaaACK4BGAYYCw/s35/*\" style=\"border: 1px solid rgb(238, 238, 238); max-width: 36px;\" /></div>\n<div class=\"comment-block\" id=\"c457628482862782522\" style=\"margin-left: 48px; position: relative;\">\n<div class=\"comment-header\" id=\"bc_0_81M\" kind=\"m\" style=\"margin: 0px 0px 8px;\">\n<cite class=\"user blog-author\" style=\"font-style: normal; font-weight: bold;\"><a href=\"https://www.blogger.com/profile/14410812789424637654\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration-line: none;\">Capt. Ajit Vadakayil</a></cite><span class=\"icon user blog-author\" style=\"background-image: url(&quot;data:image/png; background-repeat: no-repeat; display: inline-block; font-weight: bold; height: 18px; margin: 0px 0px -4px 6px; width: 18px;\"></span><span class=\"datetime secondary-text\" style=\"margin-left: 6px;\"><a href=\"https://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2011/12/ie-irodov-tribute-to-russian-professor.html?showComment=1540854081200#c457628482862782522\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration-line: none;\">October 30, 2018 at 4:31 AM</a></span></div>\n<div class=\"comment-content\" id=\"bc_0_81MC\" style=\"margin-bottom: 8px; text-align: justify;\">\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\">YASKA ( 5800 BC )</span></b> GETS THE VADAKAYIL PRIZE ( BELATED )..<br />\n<br />\nAAA ) HERE IS THE LIST OF MAHA MERUS WHO FOOLED THE WORLD , WHOM I HAVE TRASHED INTO THE GARBAGE BIN OF THE PLANET.<br />\n<br />\nGARBAGE BUCKET LIST:<br />\n<br />\n1) BERTRAND RUSSEL<br />\n2) ROMILA THAPAR<br />\n3) IRFAN HABIB<br />\n4) NOAM CHOMSKY<br />\n5) RAMCHANDRA GUHA<br />\n6) SHELDON POLLOCK<br />\n7) SIGMUND FREUD<br />\n8) GEORG WILHELM HEGEL<br />\n9) AMARTYA SEN<br />\n10) WENDY DONIGER<br />\n11) FREIDRICH WILHELM NIETZSCHE<br />\n12) IMMANUEL KANT<br />\n13 ) BARUCH SPINOZA<br />\n14) ALBERT EINSTEIN<br />\n15) ISAAC NEWTON<br />\n16) GUGLEILMO MARCONI<br />\n17) CHARLES DARWIN<br />\n18) KARL MARX<br />\n19) MAX WEBER<br />\n20) THOMAS ALVA EDISON<br />\n21) FIBONACCI<br />\n22) BARKHA DUTT<br />\n23) ADMIRAL LN RAMDAS , WIFE LALITA AND DAUGHTER KAVITA.<br />\n24) EDWARD BERNAYS<br />\n25) JOHN DEWEY<br />\n26) GEORGE IVANOVICH GURDJEIFF<br />\n27) PETER D OUPENSKY<br />\n28) OPRAH WINFREY<br />\n29) RICHARD BANDLER AND JOHN GRINDER<br />\n30) CHRISTIANE AMANPOUR<br />\n31) STEPHEN HAWKING<br />\n32) SIDNEY HOOK<br />\n33) ALFRED KINSEY<br />\n34) BARACK OBAMA<br />\n35) AYN RAND<br />\n36) WILHELM WUNDT<br />\n<br />\nNOTE: MENTAL MIDGETS LIKE ROMILA THAPAR , IRFAN HABIB , RAMACHANDRA GUHA, SHELDON POLLOCK, WENDY DONIGER , BARKHA DUTT , RAMDAS FAMILY MUST BE THANKFUL THAT THEY ARE INCLUDED AMONG A LIST OF CEREBRAL GIANTS<br />\n<br />\n#########################<br />\n<br />\nBBB ) HERE ARE PEOPLE WHO MADE A DENT IN THE UNIVERSE\u2014 THEY GET THE \"VADAKAYIL PRIZE\". THIS IS NOT A VESTED \u201cNOBEL PRIZE \u201c<br />\n<br />\n1) NIKOLA TESLA<br />\n2) DIMITRI MENDELEYEEV<br />\n3) IE IRODOV<br />\n4) ARYABHATTA ( 2700 BC)<br />\n5) SRINIVASAN RAMANUJAN<br />\n6) CHANAKYA ( 372 BC )<br />\n7) ADI SHANKARACHARYA ( 2000 BC )<br />\n8) APOLLONIUS ( AN INDIAN SAGE \u2013WHO LEGACY WAS SHIFTED ON TO A COOKED UP JESUS IN 325 AD )<br />\n9) \"JOHN DOE\"<br />\n10) JULIAN ASSANGE<br />\n11) SWAMI CHINMAYANANDA<br />\n12) GARY STEPHEN WEBB<br />\n13) GEORGE ORWELL.<br />\n13) CESAR MILLAN<br />\n14) HENRY FORD.<br />\n15) PANINI ( 5500 BC )<br />\n16) BHARTRHARI ( 7000 BC )<br />\n17) PATANJALI ( 5000 BC )<br />\n18) MANU (8300 BC)<br />\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\">19) YASKA ( 5800 BC )</span></b><br />\n<br />\nCCC) DOWN THE SHIT HOLE----<br />\n<br />\n1) SUHEL SETH<br />\n2) PRITISH NANDI<br />\n3) DILIP CHERIAN<br />\n4) PRANNOY JAMES ROY<br />\n5) AROON PURIE<br />\n6) VINEET JAIN<br />\n7) SHEKHAR GUPTA<br />\n8) SAGARIKA GHOSE AND HUSBAND RAJDEEP SARDESAI<br />\n9) SHOBHAA DE<br />\n10) SIDHARTH VARADARAJAN AND WIFE NANDINI SUNDAR<br />\n11) KAMALHAASAN<br />\n12) AUDREY TRUSCHKE<br />\n13) NOSTRODAMUS<br />\n14) MANI SHANKAR AIYAR<br />\n15) VERGHESE KURIEN<br />\n16) MS SWAMINATHAN<br />\n17 DEVDUTT PATTANAIK<br />\n<br />\ncapt ajit vadakayil<br />\n..</div>\n</div>\n</li>\n</ol>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Maharishi Yaska ( 5800\nBC ) wrote the Nirukta-- the discipline of \"etymology\" (explanation\nof words) within Sanskrit grammatical tradition.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nirukta is a technical treatise on etymology,\nlexical category and the semantics of Sanskrit words. Nirukta is the study\nconcerned with correct interpretation of Sanskrit words in the Vedas<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nirukta\n(Sanskrit),&nbsp; means \"uttered,\npronounced, explained, expressed, defined, loud\".&nbsp; It also refers to the etymological\ninterpretation of a word, also the name of such works<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The related Sanskrit\nnoun nirukti\u1e25 means \"poetical derivation\" or \"explanation of a\nword\u201d<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Yaska developed a\nsemantic analysis of words, by breaking them down into their components, and\nthen combined them in the context they were used to propose what the archaic\nwords mean..&nbsp; He pointed out that meaning\nand the etymology of words are always context dependent. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Nirukta attempts to\nexplain how certain words get to have their meanings, especially in the context\nof interpreting the Vedic texts. It includes a system of rules for forming\nwords from roots and affixes, and a glossary of irregular words, and formed the\nbasis for later lexicons and dictionaries. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">It consists of three\nparts, viz.:(i) Naighantuka, a collection of synonyms; (ii) Naigama, a collection\nof words peculiar to the Vedas, and (iii) Daivata, words relating to deities\nand sacrifices.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Nirukta was one of\nthe six vedangas or compulsory ritual subjects in syllabus of Sanskrit\nscholarship in ancient India.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Words are created\naround object-agent, according to Yaska, to express external or internal\nreality perceived by man, and are one of six modifications of Kriya (action)\nand Bhava (dynamic being), namely being born, existing, changing, increasing,\ndecreasing and perishing<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nirukta covers\netymology, and is the study concerned with correct interpretation of Sanskrit\nwords in the Vedas.&nbsp; Vyakarana deals with\nlinguistic analysis to establish the exact form of words to properly express\nideas, while Nirukta focuses on linguistic analysis to help establish the\nproper meaning of the words, given the context they are used in.&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sanskrit noun nirukti\u1e25\nmeans \"poetical derivation\" or \"explanation of a word\u201d<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Words are created\naround object-agent, according to Yaska, to express external or internal\nreality perceived by man, and are one of six modifications of Kriya (action)\nand Bhava (dynamic being), namely being born, existing, changing, increasing,\ndecreasing and perishing.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Yaska views words as\nthe main carriers of meaning -- that words have a primary or preferred\nontological status in defining meaning,<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nirukta, means\n\"uttered, pronounced, explained, expressed, defined, loud\". It also\nrefers to the etymological interpretation of a word, also the name of such\nworks.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Yaska defines four main\ncategories of words:--<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">nama \u2013 nouns or\nsubstantives<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">akhyata \u2013 verbs<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">upasarga \u2013 pre-verbs or\nprefixes<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">nipata \u2013 particles,\ninvariant words ( prepositions)<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The meaning of Vedic\npassages has to be understood through context, purpose stated, subject matter\nbeing discussed, what is stated, how, where and when. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Yaska, in his famous\ntext titled Nirukta, asserts that Rigveda in the ancient tradition, can be\ninterpreted in three ways - from the perspective of religious rites\n(adhiyajna), from the perspective of the deities (adhidevata), and from the\nperspective of the soul (adhyatman)<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The fourth way to interpret\nthe Rigveda also emerged in the ancient times, wherein the gods mentioned were\nviewed as symbolism for legendary individuals or narratives.</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"></span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The original idea of\nSphota goes back to the Vedic age when Vak or speech was considered to be a\nmanifestation of the all \u2013 pervading Brahman , and Pranava (Aum) was regarded\nas the primordial speech sound from which all forms of Vak were supposed to\nhave evolved.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This provided the model\nupon which the Vyakarana philosophers based their concept of Sphota. Indeed Sphota\nis often identified with Pranava.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">For Bhartrhari, Vac or\nspeech is the means to all knowledge and is the essence of consciousness. He\nregards speech as the verbal expression of a thought that arises in a person\u2019s\nconsciousness. If there is no consciousness, he argues, there would be no speech.\nSpeech (Vac) is indeed an outward form (Vargupta) of consciousness (chetana ).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Yaska describes speech\n(Vac) as the divine gift to humans to clearly express their thoughts (devim\nvacam ajanayanta- Nir. 11.29); and, calls the purified articulate speech as\nPaviravi \u2013 sharp as the resonance (tanyatu) of the thunderbolt which originates\nfrom an invisible power (Tad devata vak paviravi. paviravi cha divya Vac\ntanyatus tanitri vaco\u2019nyasyah \u2013 Nir. 12.30).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Vac, the\nspeech-principle (Vac-tattva), has numerous attributes and varied connotations\nin the Rig-Veda.&nbsp; Vac is not mere speech.\nIt is something more sacred than ordinary speech; and , carries with it a far\nwider significance.&nbsp; Vac is the truth\n(ninya vachasmi); and, is&nbsp; the index of\nthe integrity of one\u2019s inner being.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A true-speech (Satya-vac) honestly reflects\nthe vision of the Rishi, the seer. It is through such sublime Vac that the true\nnature of objects, as revealed to the Rishis (kavyani kavaye nivacana), is\nexpressed in pristine poetry. Their superb ability to grasp multiple dimensions\nof human life, ideals and aspirations is truly remarkable.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Vac is thus a medium of expression of the\nspiritual experience of the Rig Vedic intellectuals who were highly dexterous\nusers of the words. Being free from falsehood, Vac is described in the Rig-Veda\nas illuminating or inspiring noble thoughts (cetanti sumatlnam).</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">dharmam cadharmam ca\nsatyam canrtam ca sadhu casadhu ca hrdayajnam cahrdayajnam ca; yad-vai van\nnabhavisyat na dharmo nadharmo vyajnapayisyat, na satyam nanrtam na sadhu\nna\u2019sadhu na hrdayajno na\u2019hrdayajna vag-eva etat sarvam vijnapayati, vacam\nupassveti.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Chandogya Upanishad\n(7.2.1) asserts that Vac ( speech)&nbsp;\nis&nbsp; deeper than name (worldly\nknowledge) \u2013 Vag-vava namno bhuyasi&nbsp;\n\u2013&nbsp; because speech is what\ncommunicates (Vac vai vijnapayati) all outer worldly knowledge as well as what\nis right and what is wrong (dharmam cadharmam) ; what is true and what is false\n(satyam canrtam ca); what is good and what is bad (sadhu casadhu ca); and, what\nis pleasant and what is unpleasant ( hrdayajnam cahrdayajnam ca).&nbsp; Speech alone makes it possible to understand\nall this (vag-eva etat sarvam vijnapayati). Worship Vac (vacam upassveti).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Vac when translated\ninto English is generally rendered as Word. That, however, is not a very\nsatisfactory translation. Vac might, among many other things, also mean speech,\nvoice, utterance, language, sound or word; but, it is essentially the creative\nforce that brings forth all forms expressions as also the existence.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">It is an\nemanation from out of silence which is the Absolute. Vac is also the river and\nthe embodied or god-personified as word, as well. It may not, therefore, be\nappropriate to translate Vac as Word in all events. One, therefore, always\nneeds to take into account the context of its usage.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">As speech, the term V\u0101k\nor V\u0101c (</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;mangal&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u0935\u093e\u0915\u094d</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">),\ngrammatically, is a feminine noun. Vac is variously referred to \u2013 Syllable\n(akshara or Varna), word (Sabda), sentence (vakya), speech (Vachya), voice\n(Nada or Dhvani), language (bhasha) and literature (Sahitya).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">While in the Rig-Veda,\nthe Yajnas are a means for the propitiation of the gods, in the Brahmanas\nYagnas become&nbsp; very purpose of human\nexistence ; they are the ends in themselves. Many of the Brahmana texts are\ndevoted to the exposition of the mystic significance of the various elements of\nthe ritual (Yajna-kriya).&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The priests who were the adepts in explaining the\nobjectives, the significance, the symbolisms and the procedural details of the\nYajnas came into prominence. The all-knowing priest who presides over&nbsp; , and directs the&nbsp; course and conduct of&nbsp; the Soma sacrifice is designated as Brahma;\nwhile the three other sets of priests who chant the mantras are named as hotar,\nadhvaryu, and udgatru<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Here, Brahman is the\ndefinitive voice (final-word); while the chanting of the mantras&nbsp;&nbsp; by the other three priests is taken to be\nVac. Brahma (word) and Vac (speech) are said to be partners working closely\ntowards the good (shreya)&nbsp;&nbsp; and for the\nfulfilment of the performer or the patron\u2019s (Yajamana) aspirations\n(kamya).&nbsp; And, Brahma the one who\npresides and&nbsp;&nbsp; controls the course of the\nYajna is accorded a higher position over the chanters of the mantras. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">It was said; Vac\n(chanting) extends so far as the Brahma allows (ya\u00e1vad br\u00e1hma vistham ta\u00e1vatii\nva\u00e1k\u2013 RV.10.114.8).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">It was said;&nbsp;&nbsp; if word is flower, speech is the garland.\nAnd, if Vac is the weapons, it is Brahma that sharpens them \u2013 cod\u00e1yaami ta\na\u00e1yudhaa v\u00e1cobhih s\u00e1m te sh\u00edshaami br\u00e1hmanaa v\u00e1yaamsi. (RV 10.120.5 and\n9.97.34)<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">Bhart\u1e5bhari also\nasserted</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">that, all knowledge is\nillumined through words, and it is quite not possible to have cognition that is\nfree from words (tasm\u0101d arthavidh\u0101\u1e25 sarv\u0101\u1e25 \u015babdam\u0101tr\u0101su ni\u015brit\u0101\u1e25 \u2013 Vakyapadiya:\n1.123); \u2018no thought is possible without language\u2019; and \u2019there is no cognition\nwithout the process of words\u2019.</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\"></span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u2018Bhartrhari\u2019 glorifies\nin his \u2018Vakyapadiya\u2019, the greatness of the Goddess of speech. And he also\nasserts that it is \u2018Vak\u2019 alone created the entire Cosmos.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">And, Bhartrhari\ndeclares- \u2018It is Vac which has created all the worlds\u2019- vageva viswa bhuvanani\njajne (Vakyapadiya. 1.112)<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The concept of Vac&nbsp; was extended&nbsp;\nto cover oral and&nbsp; aural&nbsp; forms such as : expression , saying , phrase&nbsp; ,&nbsp;\nutterance sentence, and also the languages of all sorts including\ngesture (ingita).<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"></span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Vac is the word\nprinciple that gives expression to the latent or un-manifest thoughts, feelings\nand impulses. And at the same time, for Bhartrhari, all forms of awareness\nimply the presence of words. That is to say; language is an integral part of\nour consciousness.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Unfolding of speech\n(Vac) takes place, at least, in two stages. The first one is the thought that\nflashes and takes a form within. And, the other is that which comes out as\naudible speech riding the vehicle of words and sentences; attempting to\ntransport the idea that arose within.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The former is intuition (Prathibha) the flash of insight that springs\nup; and, the latter is the effort that is exerted, both internally and\nexternally, to put it out.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Yaska says that all\nkinds of creatures and objects created by God speak a language of their own,\neither articulate or in-articulate (devastam sarvarupah pasavo vadanti, vyakta\nvac-ascha- avyakta- vacacha \u2013 Nir. 11.29).&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">He says that the Vac of humans is intelligible, articulate (vyakta vaco\nmanushyadayah) and distinct (Niruktam); while the speech of the cows (animals)\nis indistinct (avyakta vaco gavayah).&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">It was said; the extant\nof Vac is as wide as the earth and fire. Vac is even extolled as having\npenetrated earth and heaven, holding together all existence. As Yaska remarks:\nVac is omnipresent and eterna1 (vyaptimattvat tu Sabdasya \u2013 Nir.I.2)<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Vac (word) belongs to\nboth the worlds \u2013 the created and un-created.&nbsp;\nIt is both the subject of speech and the object of speech.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Tantra ideology\nidentified Vac with the vibrations of the primordial throb (adya-spanda) that\nset the Universe in motion; and , said&nbsp;\nthat all objects of the Universe are created by&nbsp; that sound \u2013artha-srsteh puram\nsabda-srstih.&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Vac is, verily, the\nvery principle underlying every kind of sound, speech and language in nature.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">And, Vac goes beyond\nspeech. Vac is indeed both speech and&nbsp;\nconsciousness (chetana), as all actions and powers are grounded in Vac.\nIt is the primordial energy out of which all existence originates and subsists.\nVac is also the expression of truth.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Chatvaari vaak\nparimitaa padaani / taani vidur braahmaanaa ye manishinaah. Guhaa trini nihitaa\nneaengayanti / turiyam vaacho manushyaa vadanti. (Rigveda Samhita \u2013 1.164.45-\n5000 BC)</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u201cVac has four quarters;\nonly the wise that are well trained, endowed with intelligence and\nunderstanding know them all. For the rest; the three levels remain concealed\nand motionless. Mortals speak only with the fourth (RV. 1.164.45).\u201d<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Vac is sometimes\nidentified with waters, the primeval principle for the creation of the\nUniverse.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In the Vak Suktha or\nDevi Suktha&nbsp; of Rig Veda (RV.10. 10.125),\nApah, the waters, is conceived as the birth place of Vac. And, Vac who springs\nforth from waters touches all the worlds with her flowering body and gives\nbirth to all existence. She indeed is Prakrti.&nbsp;\nVac is the creator, sustainer and destroyer. In an intense and highly\ncharged superb piece of inspired poetry Vac declares \u201cI sprang from waters\nthere from I permeate the infinite expanse with a flowering body. I move with\nRudras and Vasus. I walk with the Sun and other Gods. It is I who blows like\nthe wind creating all the worlds\u201d.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Ultimately, Vac is\nidentified with Brahman, the Absolute.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">It is the Vac that\nbrings the cosmos into existence. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhartrhari, &nbsp;places the word-principle \u2013 Vac \u2013 at the very\ncore (Bija) of existence That Vac, \u2013 according to Bhartrhari is not merely the\ncreator and sustainer of the universe but is also the sum and substance of it.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"></span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhartrhari\u2019s concept of\nthe speech-principle Sabda-tattva or Sabda-Brahman the fundamental basis of the\nall existence and of speech, virtually equates to the concept of Para Vac, the\nSupreme Consciousness<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">And, Vac as\nSabda-Brahman is the creative force that brings forth all existence. Vac is\nalso the consciousness (chit, samvid), vital energy (prana shakthi) that\nvibrates (spanda). It is an emanation from out of silence, which is the\nAbsolute.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">That Sabda-tattva\n(Sabdasya tattvam or Sabda eva tattvam) of Bhartrhari is of the nature of the\nAbsolute; and, there is no distinction between Sabda Brahman and Para Brahman\nthe Supreme Principle (Para tattva).&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Vac was considered\nmanifestation of all-pervading Brahman; and, Pranava (Aum) was regarded the\nprimordial speech-sound from which all forms of speech emanated</span><br />\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Maharishis believed\nin a cyclic view of creation with no absolute &nbsp;beginning. The whole of the cosmos, &nbsp;has constantly been going on through cycles of\ncreation-dissolution, creation-dissolution. . .beginning- lessly. At the\ndissolution of each cycle a seed or trace ( samskara) is left behind out of\nwhich the next cycle arises. It is an agricultural image of seed-flower-seed. .\n. .</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The significant thing\nto note in relation to the Vedas is that the nature of the seed, from which\neach cycle of creation bursts forth, is described as \u201cDivine Word.\u201d</span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The language of the\nVeda is \u201crhythm not composed by the intellect but heard, a divine Word that\ncame vibrating out of&nbsp; the Infinite to\nthe inner audience of the man who had previously&nbsp; made himself fit for the impersonal\nknowledge.\u201d<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">While the Vedas\ncontained in seed form the essence of later&nbsp;\nIndian thought on language, it fell to the PratiSakhyas to prescribe\nrules for prosody, phonetics, accentuation and sandhi&nbsp; and thereby ensure that the oral form of the\nVeda would be preserved and passed on with little loss or distortion. In\nthe&nbsp; Indian tradition, language is\nthought to be truly and most fully experienced only in its oral form</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Sandhi is a technical term in Sanskrit grammar\nwhich refers to the&nbsp; rules of euphonic combination\nexperienced only in its oral form. The written word is a secondary thing\ndeveloped only for heuristic teaching purposes&nbsp;\nand as an aid for those too dull to remember the important texts&nbsp; by heart. For the Indian the criterion form\nof language is not written but oral, and the .&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Pratishakhyas&nbsp; play the important\nrole of keeping the oral form disciplined and pure in its presentation.&nbsp; Pratishakhyas&nbsp;\ncollectively constituting four treatises, are the earliest of the\nShikshas: works dealing with the phonetic aspects of the Sanskrit language used\nin Vedas.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">These works mainly pertain to euphonic permutation and combination of\nletters and special characteristics of their pronunciation as they prevailed in\nvarious schools of Vedic studies. One of the Pratisakhyas deal with the\nphonetic aspects of the Rig Veda.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The\nPratisakhya works are neither concerned with the sense of words, nor with their\ndivision into bases and affixes, nor with their etymology. They contain, more\nor less,Vedic passages arranged from the point of view of Sandhi.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sandhi&nbsp;\n(joining) is a cover term for a wide variety of sound changes that occur\nat morpheme or word boundaries. Examples include fusion of sounds across word\nboundaries and the alteration of one sound depending on nearby sounds or the\ngrammatical function of the adjacent words.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sandhi belongs to\nmorphophonology.&nbsp; It is the process\nwhereby the form of a word changes as a result of its position in an utterance\n(e.g. the change from a to an before a vowel). In Sanskrit, small words\n(morphemes) are combined to form compound words through a process known as\nSandhi.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sandhi splitting is the process of splitting a given compound word into\nits constituent morphemes. Although rules governing word splitting exists in\nthe language, it is highly challenging to identify the location of the splits\nin a compound word..&nbsp;&nbsp; Sandhi is\nmodification of the form or sound of a word under the influence of an adjacent\nword<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Knowledge of the Vedas,\ntherefore, is not simply \u201cbook-learning\u201d &nbsp;of the contents or main ideas, as is promoted\nby modern western scholarship. In the Indian tradition, language is considered to\nbe fully alive only when spoken.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Thus knowledge of the Vedas includes and\nrequires the ability to speak the text with correct accent, metre and so on.\nThe fact that the vast majority of the Vedic hymns are poems made attention to\nthe details of form specified in the Pratishakhyas even more important. &nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Pratishakhyas is concerned mainly with the\nchanges, euphonic and others, in the Pada text of the Samhita as compared with\nthe running text, the Samhita itself. The Pratisakhya works are neither\nconcerned with the sense of words, nor with their division into bases and\naffixes, nor with their etymology. They contain, more or less,Vedic passages\narranged from the point of view of Sandhi.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhartrhari, begins his\nVakyapadiya with a metaphysical enquiry into the nature and origin of language\nin relation to Brahman, but then goes on in Chapters Two and Three to explore\ntechnical grammatical points involved in the everyday use of language.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Stress on the oral or\nspoken form is an important aspect of the Indian view of language. Thinking is\nseen as internal speaking to which not enough prana or breath energy has been\nadded to make it overt.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Writing is merely a coded recording which can never\nperfectly represent all the nuances of the spoken word, and is therefore always\nsecondary. With regard to the relationship between written and spoken language,\nthe Indian approach is opposite to that taken in modern western\nscholarship.&nbsp; .</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;In the earliest\nPratiSakhyas, or rules for speaking the Vedas, the first formulations of\nSanskrit Grammar may be found.&nbsp; Vak or\nspeech was taken as a manifestation of the all-pervading Brahman.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The\nmantra&nbsp; AUM was regarded as the\nprimordial speech-sound from which all forms of vak are thought to have\nevolved. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Bhartrhari develops his theory of language by\nmaintaining that the sphota, the meaning-whole, is something over and above the\nuttered or written letters. . At first the word exists in the mind of the\nspeaker as a unity or sphota. &nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When he\nutters it, he produces a sequence of different sounds &nbsp;so that it appears to have differentiation.\nThe listener, although &nbsp;first hearing a\nseries of sounds, ultimately perceives the utterance &nbsp;as a unity\u2014\u201cthe light bulb coming on\u201d image of\nthe cartoon. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This \u201cah ha !\u201d\nexperience of the listener is his mental perception of the same sphota with\nwhich the speaker began, and it is &nbsp;then\nthat the meaning of the word first seen by the speaker is also known by the\nhearer.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Contrary to most theories of communication, Bhartrhari\u2019s view is that\nmeaning is not conveyed from the speaker to the hearer, rather, the spoken\nwords serve &nbsp;only as the stimulus to\nreveal or uncover the meaning which &nbsp;was\nalready present in the mind of the hearer. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">.<o:p></o:p></span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">According to Bhartrhari\nthese are the three levels through which vak or language passes whenever one speaks.\nVak, which is at first quite internal, is gradually externalized for the\npurpose of speaking. Hearing of course operates in the reverse direction.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">In this\nway Bhartrhari accounts for the complete continuum of cognition. Whether one is\ndealing with factual scientific language or a poem which can be understood on\nvarious levels, Bhartrhari\u2019s Sphota Theory would seem to provide an adequate explanation.</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The logic of\nBhartrhari\u2019s philosophy of language is that the whole is prior to the parts. This\nresults in an ascending hierarchy of speech levels. The word is subsumed by the\nsentence, the sentence by the paragraph, the paragraph by the chapter, the\nchapter by the book, and so on, until all speech is identified with Brahman.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhartrihari\u2019s\nVakyapadiya ( words in a sentence ) is written in verse form so that it will be\neasier to memorize. For this reason it contains highly compressed treatments.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The first chapter&nbsp; of his renowned work the Vakyapadiya,&nbsp; asserts the identity of the Sabda tattva (the\nWord principle) with the Absolute Reality, the Brahman (v\u0101g vai brahmeti) which\nis without a beginning (Anadi), without an end (Nidana) and is imperishable\n(Aksharam). <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">That Brahman, he avers,\nis&nbsp; One (ekam eva) and is the essence of\nSabda from which the whole of existence is derived. And, it transforms\n(Vivartate) itself into speech; as words, their meanings (Artha) and also the\nuniverse (jagato yataha).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;(Anadi-nidhanam Brahma sabda-tattvam\nyad-aksharam / vivartate artha-bhavena prakriya jagato yatah \u2013 VP. 1.1)<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Thus, according to\nBhartrhari, Sabda Brahman is the ultimate ground of all existence; and, the\nSabda tattva is the first principle of the universe. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">At a metaphysical\nlevel, Bhartrhari conceives the ultimate Reality as One-without\u2013a second (Ekam\nEva). It is of the nature of the Word (Sabda eva tattvam) and from it are\nmanifested all objects (including speech) and the whole of existence.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhartrhari was a\nAdvaita philosopher; and, he explained everything in terms of his metaphysical\nview point. Thus, at the top of the language hierarchy there is only one\nindivisible reality present; and that transforms into many.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">At a metaphysical\nlevel, Bhartrhari conceives the ultimate Reality as One-without\u2013a second (Ekam\nEva). It is of the nature of the Word (Sabda eva tattvam) and from it are\nmanifested all objects (including speech) and the whole of existence.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhartrhari said\nthat&nbsp; the language we speak is the medium\nof expression of the Ultimate Reality communicated through meaning-bearing\nwords. It leads us across the external appearances and diversities to the core\nof the Reality which is the source and the underlying unity beneath everything.</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Here, the Real is the\nluminous Truth which needs to be rediscovered by every speaker. The Real breaks\nforth (sphut) through the medium of speech (Sabda). And, Sabda is not mere\nmeans to the Reality, but it is the very Truth and Reality (Shabda-Brahman).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Vakyapadiya is\nbased on Bhartrhari questioning of why something that exists comes into being\nand how something that does not exist comes into being . For him, language is\nthe manifestation of Brahman, and it constitutes the world .<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Vakyapadiya is split\ninto three kandas, respectively called Brahma-kanda (Agama-kanda), Vakya-kanda,\nand Prakirna-kanda, all of which are composed in karikas .&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The first two\nchapters discuss metaphysical ideas concerning the concept of sabdabrahman and\nthe structure and meaning of sentences, while the third deals with issues\nrelating to words.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">According to\nBhartrhari, the sentence is indivisible and is the unit of expression, which is\nwhy the focus of first two kandas is on the vakya sentence . The real structure\nof language is formed from the words and sentences in our speech and written\nrecords , and from this,&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhartrhari notes that knowledge and the proper use of\nwords reveals spiritual dharma, which leads to an understanding of pratyaya.\nAccording to the Vakyapadiya, there are eight subjects within grammar that must\nbe dealt with.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">These subjects are: sentences and words, word and sentence\nmeanings, fitness or compatibility, spiritual merit, stems/suffixes (etc.),\nmeanings of stems/suffixes (etc.), causality, and knowledge of the meaning of\nthe correct words. These are each discussed in their respective chapters of the\nVakyapadiya.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhartrhari explains; at\nfirst, the intention (iccha) exists in the mind of the speaker as a unity or\nSphota. In the process of giving an outward form to that impulse or thought, he\nproduces a series of different sounds in a sequence where one sound follows its\nprevious one.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">It might appear as though those word-sounds are separated in time\nand space. But, they are indeed part and parcel of one and the same single\nentity \u2013 the sentence which puts out, in full, the intention of the speaker.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The communication of a sentence and its meaning is not complete until its last\nword is uttered. Thus, though the word-sounds reach the listener in a sequence,\neventually they all merge into one; and, are grasped by the listener as a\nsingle unit.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The same Sphota which originated in speaker\u2019s mind re-manifests in\nlistener\u2019s mind, conveying the intended meaning.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In the Vakyapadiya, the\nconcept of Sabda occupies a central role; Bhartrhari equates it with Sphota to\nshow the metaphysical nature of the language.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">According to\nBhartrhari, the perfect perception is that in which there is identity between\nthe object (namely, the Sphota) and the form of its cognition (namely, words or\nthe letters of sounds). This special kind of perception is held to be function\nof mind, rather than of the external senses.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The sphota is the\nperfect gist of language and is the cornerstone of all linguistic process. The\netymological meaning of sphota is that which bursts. In this context, the gist\nof language which bursts itself is the sphota. It is the internal&nbsp; realness of the sentences which establish\nlanguage.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhartrhari formulates his sphota theory in order to show that&nbsp; without the internal realness of language\nthere can be no arrant realizing of the meaning and operation of language.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">According to\nBhartrhari, sphota is the original sound produced by various vocal organs with\nthe contact of various places of articulation<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhartrhari says that\nword and meaning are inseparable units. If we go to the theoretical sense of\nsphota, we can&nbsp; realize that the \u2018word\u2019\nmeans sabdatattva (sound principle), arthatattva (meaning principle) and\npratibha (intuition).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">According to\nBhartrhari, the term sabda is only an equivalent word for sphota. The real word\nor the real sphota is the \u2018Brahman\u2019 itself and it is the Ultimate Reality,\nhence it bears for the akhandavakyasphota.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhartrhari believes\nthat sphota is a two sided coin that is indivisible and changeless. One of its\nproportions is the&nbsp; sound form and the\nother is the meaning assuming unit. &nbsp;It\nis believed that sphota along with expressing the meaning also expresses itself..</span>&nbsp;</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhartrhari\nsupposes that a word has a double power, i.e. a word can express both the\nmeaning and the expressed thing.&nbsp; To him,\nthe eternal word Sphota is without parts. The cause of the word is Brahman..</span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">He\nbegins the discussion on the theory of Sphota with the observation that words\nor sentences can be considered under two aspects, as sound patterns and\nmeaning-bearing symbols.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sphota is classified\ninto a number of&nbsp; varieties. They are Varnasphota,\nPadasphota and Vakyasphota.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">It is of three types:\n1) 'varnasphota' which conveys the meaning of letters, 2) 'padasphota' which\ncommunicates the meaning of a word, and 3) 'vakyasphota which communicates the\nmeaning of the sentence<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Meaningfulness is the\nfundamental aspect in all these cases. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Sphota shabda which\nsi nothing but the consciousness of the speaker appears in the form of prakrita\ndvani and vaikraita dvani which are destructible. The invisible sphota appears\nas divisible in the stages of prakrita dvani and vaikraita dvani by taking on\nit , the qualities of sound.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">While\nprakrita dvani and vaikraita dvani are only appearance ( vivarta ) of sphota ,\none word in a sentence or one phenome in a word should be enoughto communicate\nthe shhota shabda in the mind of the listener.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The abstract sound;\npattern with the time sequence is - called Prakrta dhvani. It is the external\naspect of the language. The internal aspect of the language is phota and is\ndirectly attached to the meaning. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhartrhari emphasizes\nthe fact that a word has double power.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">It can convey an idea of the form&nbsp; of an expression as well as its content. He\nexplains it by means of various illustrations.
