It is at the level of direct intuition, and\ntherefore, must be finally understood through experience<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Pasyanti represents the\nintellectual consciousness, a state of abstract knowledge, like an idea which\nhas not yet been expressed in words. &nbsp;&nbsp;Pashyanti is the thought form. &nbsp;Pasyanti literally means observing or seeing\none's self. &nbsp;In the pasyanti stage sound\npossesses qualities such as color and form. &nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When\nsound goes up to the navel with the bodily air in vibratory form without any\nparticular syllable (varna), yet connected with the mind, it is known as Pashyanti-vaak.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Pasyanti observes and\nanalyses her impending changes in the heart, throat and the tongue, where the\nsound finally attains audibility. Within the Pasyanti-vaak exists the nature's\nIccha-shakti, or the power of will.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When sound goes up to\nthe naval with the bodily air in vibratory form without any particular syllable\n(varna), yet connected with the mind, it is pashyanti-vak. &nbsp;Within the pashyanti-vak exists the nature's\niccha-shakti, or the power of will.&nbsp; Again,\nMaharishis with 12 strand DNA had subtle inner vision \u2013 they could experience\nthe pashyanti state of sound.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">vaikhary\u0101 madhyam\u0101y\u0101\u015b\nca pa\u015byanty\u0101\u015b caitad adbhutam / anekat\u012brthabhed\u0101y\u0101s&nbsp; trayy\u0101 v\u0101ca\u1e25&nbsp;\npara\u1e43 padam // 1.159 //<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The latent, unspoken\nthought that instinctively springs up and which is visualised, within one\u2019s\nself, is called Pashyanti Vak (thought visualized). &nbsp;The Vrtti on Vakyapadiya (1.14) presents\nPashyanti as a form of Supreme Reality, Sabda-Brahman. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Pashyanti is identified\nwith Prathibha, the flash of insight.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"></span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhartrihari associates\nthe pashyanti level of language with the concept of&nbsp; sphota. &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Sphota represents meaning as a unified whole\nthat exists in the mind of&nbsp; the speaker: &nbsp;&nbsp;When he utters it, he produces a sequence of\ndifferent sounds so&nbsp; that it appears to\nhave differentiation .&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The process of differentiation&nbsp; into sounds proceeds from the sphota at the\npashyanti level of language via madhyama, or inward thought, to expressed\nspeech at the vaikhari level.&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Pashyanti Vak\nthereafter transforms into Madhyama, the intermediate stage. It is an\nintellectual process, involving thought (Buddhi), during which the speaker\nlooks for and selects appropriate words, phrases, and their sequence, which are\ncapable of conveying his intention , clearly.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhartrhari takes a\nmetaphysical view of Sabda, the speech-principle (Sabda tattva). He compares\nthe transformation of Sabda, in three stages, with the manifestation of the\nUniverse.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Vrtti on\nVakyapadiya (1.14) presents Pashyanti as the Supreme Reality, Sabda-Brahman,\nwhich is identified with Prathibha, intuitive cognition or the first flash of\nunderstanding.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The first stage in the\ntransformation of a thought or an impulse into speech is the Pashyanti (thought\nvisualized). It is a pre-verbal or potential stage. In this stage, the latent,\nunspoken thought that instinctively springs up is visualised within one\u2019s self.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Pashyanti, which\nalso suggests the visual image of the word, is indivisible and without\ninner-sequence; in the sense, that the origin and destination of speech are\none. Here, the latent word (Sabda) and its intention or meaning (Artha)\nco-exist; and, is fused together without any differentiation. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">That is to say;\nintention is instinctive and immediate; and, it does not involve stages such\nas: analysis, speculation, drawing inferences and so on. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The transformation of a\nthought into spoken-words involves two kinds of efforts: the internal process\n(abhyantara prayatna) and the external effort (bahya prayatna). The former is\nclassified into two kinds (Pashyanti and Madhyam\u0101), while the latter (the\nexternal) is said to be of eleven kinds.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Prayatna in Sanskrit\nand Malayalam &nbsp;means \u2013 effort or\nactivity; it expresses a sense of human determination and initiative.. Prayatna\ndoes not merely mean 'effort' but 'effort at a point of articulation'.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">And, of the three\nlevels or stages of speech, Pashyanti which is identified with Prathibha\n(intuition) and Madhyam\u0101 identified with intellectual process (Buddhi) are\nregarded as subtle or internal forms of Vac; while Vaikhari is its overt\nmanifested gross form.&nbsp; These three\nforms, in turn, are identified with Sphota, Prakrta dhvani and vaikrta dhvani.\nPashyanti<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhartrhari takes a\nmetaphysical view of Sabda, the speech-principle (Sabda tattva). He compares\nthe transformation of Sabda, in three stages, with the manifestation of the\nUniverse.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Vrtti on\nVakyapadiya (1.14) presents Pashyanti as the Supreme Reality, Sabda-Brahman,\nwhich is identified with Prathibha, intuitive cognition or the first flash of\nunderstanding.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Pashyanti, which\nalso suggests the visual image of the word, is indivisible and without\ninner-sequence; in the sense, that the origin and destination of speech are\none. Here, the latent word (Sabda) and its intention or meaning (Artha)\nco-exist; and, is fused together without any differentiation.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">That is to say;\nintention is instinctive and immediate; and, it does not involve stages such\nas: analysis, speculation, drawing inferences and so on.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhartrhari employs the\nsimile of the yolk of the peachen\u2019s egg which is about to hatch. Before the\nhatching of the egg, all the flecked colours of the peacock lie dormant in\npotential state in the yolk of the egg.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Even though Bhartrihari\nconsiders Pashyanti to be the highest level of language for it is the word\nwithout temporal sequence but Pashyanti contains the inherent impulse toward\nexpression in time and space. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Pashyanti borders on\ntwo dimensions \u2013 Jagrat chetna or refined ordinary waking consciousness which\ndetermines the force of expression, and Turiya chetna or the transcendental\nconsciousness which determines the non-sequenced unity of sound and meaning\nintimated by the trace;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">These bring to the fore two kinds of infinity \u2013 that of\ndissemination, of unlimited extension within space, time and causality; and\nthat of Turiya and Pashyanti, of transcending duality through unity amidst\ndiversity.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: lime; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: lime; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2012/06/beyond-theta-state-to-turiya-capt-ajit.html\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2012/06/beyond-theta-state-to-turiya-capt-ajit.html</a><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: lime;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2013/02/the-dreamer-and-rem-sleep-witness-and.html\" style=\"background-color: lime;\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2013/02/the-dreamer-and-rem-sleep-witness-and.html</a><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The latent, unspoken\nthought that instinctively springs up and which is visualised, within one\u2019s\nself, is called Pashyanti Vak (thought visualized). The Vrtti on Vakyapadiya\n(1.14) presents Pashyanti as a form of Supreme Reality, Sabda-Brahman. And,\nPashyanti again is identified with Prathibha, the flash of insight.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Thus, the\ntransformation of a thought into spoken-words involves two kinds of efforts:\nthe internal process (abhyantara prayatna) and the external effort (bahya\nprayatna). The former is classified into two kinds (Pashyanti and Madhyam\u0101),\nwhile the latter (the external) is said to be of eleven kinds.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhartrhari takes a\nmetaphysical view of Sabda, the speech-principle (Sabda tattva). He compares\nthe transformation of Sabda, in three stages, with the manifestation of the\nUniverse.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Vrtti on\nVakyapadiya (1.14) presents Pashyanti as the Supreme Reality, Sabda-Brahman,\nwhich is identified with Prathibha, intuitive cognition or the first flash of\nunderstanding.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The first stage in the\ntransformation of a thought or an impulse into speech is the Pashyanti (thought\nvisualized). It is a pre-verbal or potential stage. In this stage, the latent,\nunspoken thought that instinctively springs up is visualised within one\u2019s self.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Pashyanti, which\nalso suggests the visual image of the word, is indivisible and without\ninner-sequence; in the sense, that the origin and destination of speech are\none. Here, the latent word (Sabda) and its intention or meaning (Artha)\nco-exist; and, is fused together without any differentiation.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">That is to say;\nintention is instinctive and immediate; and, it does not involve stages such\nas: analysis, speculation, drawing inferences and so on. At the level of\nPashyanti Vak, there is no distinction between word and meaning. And, there is\nalso no temporal sequence.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In other words; Pashyanti is the direct experience\nof Vakya-sphota,&nbsp;&nbsp; of the meaning as\nwhole of what is intended.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Pashyanti Vak\nthereafter transforms into Madhyam\u0101, the intermediate stage. It is an\nintellectual process, involving thought (Buddhi), during which the speaker\nlooks for and selects appropriate words, phrases, and their sequence, which are\ncapable of conveying his intention , clearly.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-o-Q4ThArgaw/W9RDekXQhtI/AAAAAAABexQ/k5AaPvuQAHYT3flCmo-ssIHg8xcD-RydwCLcBGAs/s1600/iDmages.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"225\" data-original-width=\"225\" height=\"400\" src=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-o-Q4ThArgaw/W9RDekXQhtI/AAAAAAABexQ/k5AaPvuQAHYT3flCmo-ssIHg8xcD-RydwCLcBGAs/s400/iDmages.jpg\" width=\"400\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background: aqua; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 22.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">MADHYAMA</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 22.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background: aqua; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 22.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Madhyama vani is the\nintermediate unexpressed state of sound experienced in the heart.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Madhyamaa represents\nthe mental consciousness&nbsp; .&nbsp;&nbsp; Pasyanti, on reaching the Anaahata chakra or\nthe heart chakra , transforms into Madhyama vaak.&nbsp;&nbsp; Madhyamaa literally means in between or\nmiddle.&nbsp; Here there is a clear\ndistinction between the sound and the object it denotes.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Madhyama vak, is at the\nlevel of thought. &nbsp;At this level, the\nsphota is fragmented into a sequence of thoughts, words, and phrases that still\nhave to reach the level of uttered sounds<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Madhyama vak&nbsp; is a mental sound that is a little more\nsubtle than vaikhari. This is when the subtle nada begins to emerge.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Madhyama is the\nintermediate unexpressed state of sound experienced in the heart. Madhyama is\nmental speech, verbalized but unspoken, the internal monologue and dialogue; it\nexpresses j\u00f1ana shakti, the power of knowledge and wisdom (or lack\nthereof).&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Madhyama measures, evaluates,\nquestions, harnessing your rational and emotional minds to formulate the\nintentions that precipitate into words.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Madhyama vaak is more\nof a mental speech rather than the external audible speech.&nbsp; Within the Madhyama-vaak exists the nature's\nJnana-shakti, or the power of knowledge.&nbsp;\nMadhyama-vak is the intermediate unexpressed state of sound, whose seat\nis in the heart.. The middle sound is that sound which exists between the\nstates of susupti and jagrat.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Pashyanti Vak\ntransforms into an internal (antahs-amnivesini), subtle (sukshma) intellectual\nprocess (Jnana), the level of thought (buddhi-matropadana), during which the\nspeaker becomes aware (parigrihita) of the word as it arises and takes a form\nwithin him.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Madhyama (Middle)&nbsp; is the sound as perceived in the subtle or\nthe Pranic world--the thought-forms held in our mind. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Madhyama is\nparticularized into phonemes, directed to mental objects, the objects of the\ninner senses. It straddles the gulf between the noiseless conviction that is\npashyanti and the spoken word that is vaikhari.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Madhyama is sound\nhaving lower frequencies than para and pashyanti, but still subtler than the\naudible vaikhari form of sound. &nbsp;&nbsp;No\naudible effect is produced in it. &nbsp;Madhyama\nproduces very minute vibrations in the act of a whisper. &nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In an ordinary sound, two objects strike\nagainst each other in order to produce sound.&nbsp;\nBut in madhyama no two things strike violently so as to produce audible\nsound.&nbsp; The word madhyama means a middle\nsound, a whispering sound or the sound of a whisper.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Thinking or motivation\nfor conveyance of the meaning, here, does not refer to concept-formation,\nspeculation or drawing inference and so on. That intellectual process takes\nplace at &nbsp;the Madhyama.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Madhyama represents,&nbsp; in broad terms, the thinking level of the\nmind. It is the idea or series of words as conceived by the mind after hearing\nor before speaking. It may be thought of as inward speech.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Madhyama vak\u2019s association is chiefly with the\nmind or intellect (buddhi). It is the idea, or series of words, as conceived by\nthe mind after hearing or before being spoken out.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">At this level a variety\nof manifestation is possible. The same Sphota, or meaning, is capable of being\nrevealed by a variety of forms of madhyama, depending on the language adopted.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Although there is not full temporal sequence of the kind experienced in spoken\nwords, word and meaning are still distinct, and word order is present.\nTherefore, temporal sequence must also be present along with its instrumental\ncause, prana.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The \"Madhyama' can\nbe recognised at a higher level.&nbsp; The\nPasyanti can only be heard by Maharishi seers..<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The \"Madhyama' is\nsignified by the letter \"M\" in&nbsp;\nSa, Ri, Ga, Ma', Pa, Da, Ni&nbsp; which\nare the \"sapta svaras\" in Music. Music is said to have been born from\n\"Sama Veda\". \"Sa\"is Shadja, Ri is Rishabha,&nbsp; Ga is Gandhara,&nbsp; Ma is madhyama, pa is Panchama,&nbsp; Da is Daivata, and Ni is Nishada.&nbsp; Each have the baisis of the sound produced by\nbirds and animals.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-l5HEUAksgQI/W9RD-2EJ29I/AAAAAAABexg/JCpnmtFI4P0HlMv-dkXKuRlJwgpB6UbGwCLcBGAs/s1600/vFSak-2.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"380\" data-original-width=\"380\" height=\"400\" src=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-l5HEUAksgQI/W9RD-2EJ29I/AAAAAAABexg/JCpnmtFI4P0HlMv-dkXKuRlJwgpB6UbGwCLcBGAs/s400/vFSak-2.jpg\" width=\"400\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background: aqua; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 22.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">VAIKHARI</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 22.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Vaikhari \u201cis the most\nexternal and differentiated level,\u201d at which speech is uttered by the speaker\nand heard by the listener<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Pasyanti is the latent\nstage of language. At this stage the distinction between the word-forms and meaning\nare not there.&nbsp; Madhyama is the\nintermediate stage, where despite the identity of thought and language\ntheir&nbsp; distinction along with the\ndistinctive elements of words and meanings are discernible.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This stage is the\n\u2018pre-verbal\u2019 stage. And vaikhari is the \u2018verbal\u2019 stage<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This is the spoken word\nemerging from the our throat..</span> <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">.. Vaikhari resides in the throat\nchakra<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Vaikhari is the lowest\nform of sound and it signifies outward expression. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The last&nbsp; stage in the manifestation of speech is\nVaikhari.&nbsp;&nbsp; It&nbsp; is the actual sound uttered by the speaker\nand heard by the listener</span> - <span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">an articulate sound, audible to the\nexternal ear.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Vaikhari Vak &nbsp;is the final stage at which ones\u2019 thought or\nintention is put out explicitly through uttered words and sentences. Thus,\nVaikhari is the fully embodied stage of everyday speech<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">At this stage all the\npeculiarities of the speaker are present in the utterance along with the\nlinguistically relevant parts.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When sabda is spoken\nthrough the mouth with the help of syllables, that speech is Vaikhari vak.. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">And, Pashyanti Vak,\nthereafter, when it comes out of the speaker\u2019s mouth as sequenced and\nverbalized speech-form is called the Vaikhari Vak.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">It is the final stage at\nwhich ones\u2019 thought or intention is put out explicitly through uttered words\nand sentences. Thus, Vaikhari is the fully embodied stage of everyday speech.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Vaikhari the\narticulated speech, which, in a waveform, reaches the ears and to the intellect\nof the listener.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Vaikhari is the\nphysical or gross form of the subtle thought or is the outward expression of\nthe intention of the speaker. And, when it emerges as the spoken-word, it is\nthe one that is heard and apprehended by the listener, in a flash of\nunderstanding (Sphota). <o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-YteebeRt9f4/W9RFqx-3AtI/AAAAAAABeyM/jmUBQwvuW1QipSjEiPI9ZmOisgwYvW3RQCLcBGAs/s1600/1R79ttt1603.png\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"459\" data-original-width=\"472\" height=\"622\" src=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-YteebeRt9f4/W9RFqx-3AtI/AAAAAAABeyM/jmUBQwvuW1QipSjEiPI9ZmOisgwYvW3RQCLcBGAs/s640/1R79ttt1603.png\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;The process of Hearing, that is what is heard\nand grasped by the listener, of course, operates in the reverse direction.</span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A\nsound wave is a longitudinal wave--a series of compressions and rarefactions..\nHigher the frequency, higher the perceived pitch.</span>&nbsp;</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sound\nwaves are transformed into nerve impulses, to the temporal lobe of the cerebral\ncortex which is dedicated to sound. The audio range is 20 hz to 20 K Hz.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When a person wills to\nexpress a thought orally, the air (Prana) inside his body spurs and moves up.\nSabda or the Vac (speech or utterance) then manifests through Dhvani (sound\npatterns), with the assistance of appropriate&nbsp;\norgans.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In this process, the\nhead, throat, tongue, palate, teeth, lips, nose, root of the tongue and bosom\nare said to be the eight places which assist the sounds of the letters to\nbecome audible and explicit.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Vaikhari represents the\npower of action Kriyasakti. This is the plane at which the Vac gains a bodily-\nform and expression; and the intent of the speaker is transported to the\nlistener. Until this final stage, the word is still a mental (iccha) or an\nintellectual (jnana) event.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Now, the articulated word comes out in succession;\nand, gives substance and forms to ones thoughts. Vaikhari is the final stage of\ncommunication, where the word is externalized and rendered into audible sounds\n(prak\u1e5bta dhvani).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The chief\ncharacteristic of Vaikhari Vak is that it has a fully developed temporal\nsequence. At this level, the speaker\u2019s individual peculiarities (such as\naccent, voice modulation etc) are present, along with relevant parts of speech.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Vaikhari is the way\nthe word is spelt out.&nbsp; It is akin to the\nway of accent. This is produced by the vocal chords,the way speech is spoken.&nbsp; This can be understood at the human level. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Vaikhari vak is\nsequenced and verbalized speech. Vaikhari is the articulated speech, which, in\na waveform, reaches the ears and to the intellect of the listener. Vaikhari is\nthe physical form of nada that is heard and apprehended by the listener. It\ngives expression to subtler forms of vak but is not it\u2019s ultimate.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The urge to communicate\nor the spontaneous evolution of Para-pasyanti into vaikhari epitomizes, in\nminiature, the act of One becoming Many; and the subtle energy transforming\ninto a less subtle matter. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The comprehension of\nthe verbalized and sequenced vaikhari vak entails pratibha or \"flash of\ninsight\" that reveals to the listener the pasyanti vak, in the form it\noriginated within the speaker. A perfect communication is when vak is identical\nand is sequence less at both the ends.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhartrhari in his&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">Vakyapadiya says:</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">Just as light has two powers, that of being\nrevealed and that of being the revealer, similarly, all words have two distinct\npowers. No meaning is conveyed by words which by themselves are not the objects\nof knowledge..</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">And, the Madhyam\u0101, when\nit is put out explicitly through uttered words and sentences; and, when it\ncomes out of the speaker\u2019s mouth in sequenced and verbalized speech-form, set\nin motion according to his&nbsp; will,&nbsp; is called Vaikhari Vak. &nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">For the purpose of putting out the Vaikhari\nVac, the speaker employs a sentence comprising words uttered in a sequence. The\nword itself comprises letters or syllables (varnas) that follow one after the\nother in space and time.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The spoken word comes\nout of one\u2019s mouth, no doubt. However, it needs the assistance of breath and of\nseveral body parts in order to manifest itself..Vikhara literally means body;\nand, Vaikhari is that which employs bodily organs.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When a person wills to\nexpress a thought orally, the air (Prana) inside his body spurs and moves up. &nbsp;Sabda or the Vac (speech or utterance) then\nmanifests through Dhvani (sound patterns), with the assistance of\nappropriate&nbsp; organs.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The chief\ncharacteristic of Vaikhari Vak is that it has a fully developed temporal\nsequence. At this level, the speaker\u2019s individual peculiarities (such as\naccent, voice modulation etc) are present, along with relevant parts of speech.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Vaikhari is the most\nexternal and differentiated level in which vak is commonly uttered by the\nspeaker and heard by the hearer. It is prana, or breath, that enables the\norgans of articulation and hearing to produce and perceive sounds in a temporal\nsequence.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Prana/ breath is the instrumental cause of vaikhari vak. The chief\ncharacteristic of vaikhari vak is that it has a fully developed temporal sequence.\nAt this level, individual peculiarities of the speaker (e.g. accent) are\npresent along with the linguistically relevant parts of speech.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">And, the Madhyam\u0101, when\nit is put out explicitly through uttered words and sentences; and, when it\ncomes out of the speaker\u2019s mouth in sequenced and verbalized speech-form, set\nin motion according to his/her&nbsp;\nwill,&nbsp; is called Vaikhari Vak.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">For\nthe purpose of putting out the Vaikhari Vac, the speaker employs a sentence\ncomprising words uttered in a sequence. The word itself comprises letters or\nsyllables (varnas) that follow one after the other in space and time.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-HWfE04xJbGU/W9RDsIIpp7I/AAAAAAABexU/WiQpI2tb0eEFeVOBPRT078z52IbpvyrlQCLcBGAs/s1600/dRRHownload.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"225\" data-original-width=\"225\" height=\"400\" src=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-HWfE04xJbGU/W9RDsIIpp7I/AAAAAAABexU/WiQpI2tb0eEFeVOBPRT078z52IbpvyrlQCLcBGAs/s400/dRRHownload.jpg\" width=\"400\" /></a></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-_MI2dTGym1E/W9RDEI1gE4I/AAAAAAABexI/4T0AEBXn_Fkv5go21NiJ1SHNsmr7_Od2ACLcBGAs/s1600/dowDSnload.png\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"121\" data-original-width=\"418\" height=\"184\" src=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-_MI2dTGym1E/W9RDEI1gE4I/AAAAAAABexI/4T0AEBXn_Fkv5go21NiJ1SHNsmr7_Od2ACLcBGAs/s640/dowDSnload.png\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">EVERY VESTIGE OF SOUND\n, LANGUAGE AND GRAMMAR HAS BEEN LIFTED FROM ANCIENT INDIAN KNOWLEDGE BY THE\nWHITE MAN WITHOUT UNDERSTANDING..<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">UNLESS YOU HAVE\nMASTERED SANSKRIT GRAMMAR , YOU CANNOT UNDERSTAND THE VEDIC SRUTIS.. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">KEEPING A MONIER\nWILLIAMS SANSKRIT DICTIONARY ( LIKE WENDY DONIGER/ SHELDON POLLOCK/ AUDREY\nTRUCSCHE AND THEIR ILK ) WILL NOT DO.. &nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">MONIER WILLIAMS\nDICTIORARY HAS ONLY 40% OF SANSKIT WORDS.. &nbsp;&nbsp;IN SANSKRIT THERE ARE NO SYNONIUMS ( PARYAYAM\n) ..<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">HIGH LITERATURE\nMALAYALAM IS 80% SANSKRIT.. &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;MY MOTHER\nTONGUE IS MALAYALAM. I STUDIED SANSKRIT IN SCHOOL (KENDRIYA VIDYALAYA ) .. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">I KNOW THESE FAKE WHITE\nINDOLOGISTS WHO CLAIM TO KNOW SANSKRIT YET KNOW SHIT ABOUT SANSKRIT GRAMMAR..<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">VEDAS WENT ON ORAL\nROUTE FOR 330 CENTURIES BEFORE WE PENNED THEM DOWN 70 CENTURIES AGO.. &nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">IMAGINE THE BIG BANG IN THE BIBLE IS DATED AS\n4004 BC, 23RD OCT , 9 AM\u2014TEE HEEEEEEE.. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">AND THESE ARE THE WHITE\nMEN CALLING INDIANS SAVAGES.. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">JUST BECAUSE VEDAS WERE\nPENNED DOWN IN 5000 BC, DOES NOT MEAN THAT SANSKRIT WAS WRITTEN FIRST AT THAT\nTIME.. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">BHARTRHARI WAS BORN IN\n7000 BC.. &nbsp;&nbsp;HE WROTE IN GRANTHA LIPI.. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">WHEN WE WROTE POETRY\nTHE WHITE MAN WAS RUNNING AROUND NAKED DOING GRUNT GRUNT..<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">THE WHITE MAN INVADED\nINDIA, MADE US SLAVES ( DUE TO TRAITORS FROM WITHIN ) AND THEN INJECTED POISON\nINTO OUR GLORIOUS, PRICELESS CULTURE AND KNOWLEDGE BANK AND MADE US SELF\nLOATHING.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">TODAY THESE CHRISTIAN\nCONVERTS HAVE TAKEN ON THE WHITE MANs VAIKHARI \u2013 WHICH IS JUST MINDLESS NOISE<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><b>WATCH THE RIDICULOUS VIDEO\nBELOW\u2014 ( JESUS NEVER EXISTED --HE WAS COOKED UP IN 325 AD BY THE ROMAN EMPEROR CONSTANTINE THE GREAT , AT THE FIRST COUNCIL OF NICEA )&nbsp;</b></span><span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br />\n<span style=\"background-color: white; color: red; font-size: x-large;\"><b>PRAISE THE LORD-HALLELUJAAHHH</b></span><br />\n<span style=\"background-color: white; color: red; font-size: x-large;\"><b>&nbsp;&nbsp;</b></span><br />\n<span style=\"background-color: white; color: red; font-size: x-large;\"><b><br /></b></span>\n<span style=\"background-color: white; color: red; font-size: x-large;\"><b>JUMP JUMP CLAP CLAP -- PWEEEETTTT</b></span><br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/eso1oDjwclE/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/eso1oDjwclE?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3;\">WANT TO HAVE A PEEK\nINTO SANSKRIT GRAMMAR ( JUST 2 % )&nbsp; &nbsp;\u2013 &nbsp;I WILL\nGIVE YOU WHAT WIKIPEDIA SAYS WITH HALF BAKED UNDERSTANDING &nbsp;. </span>&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background: lime; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><a href=\"https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Sanskrit_Grammar/Chapter_I\">https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Sanskrit_Grammar/Chapter_I</a></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background: lime; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><a href=\"https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Sanskrit_Grammar/Chapter_II\">https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Sanskrit_Grammar/Chapter_II</a></span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background: lime; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><a href=\"https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Sanskrit_Grammar/Chapter_III\">https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Sanskrit_Grammar/Chapter_III</a></span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background: lime; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background: lime; tab-stops: 324.3pt;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background: lime; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background: lime; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><a href=\"https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Sanskrit_Grammar/Sanskrit_Index\">https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Sanskrit_Grammar/Sanskrit_Index</a></span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background: lime; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><a href=\"https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Sanskrit_Grammar/General_Index\">https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Sanskrit_Grammar/General_Index</a></span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Shabda brahmAn\nmanifests through his power of maya first as para vani in the mooladhara chakra\nat the perineum, then as pashyanti in the manipura chakra at the navel, next as\nmadhyama in the heart and then eventually as vaikhari in the throat and mouth.\nThis is the divine descent of voice.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The first three are\ninternal and yogic and can be experienced only by seers. The fourth stage is\nVaikhari is the audible speech, which is used by all human beings.&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-OhhwtYaiZl0/W9REztUyD_I/AAAAAAABex4/0_8iIeSPgv84zNp5TEUa1qBV8Ovm0wiogCLcBGAs/s1600/Ehiteheadvi69edanta.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"356\" data-original-width=\"353\" height=\"640\" src=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-OhhwtYaiZl0/W9REztUyD_I/AAAAAAABex4/0_8iIeSPgv84zNp5TEUa1qBV8Ovm0wiogCLcBGAs/s640/Ehiteheadvi69edanta.jpg\" width=\"634\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<b style=\"background-color: white;\"><span style=\"color: red;\">BELOW: FEW VIDEOS GIVE A PEEK OF PANINIs GRAMMAR WHICH HAS REMAINED UNCHANGED FOR 7500 YEARS&nbsp;</span></b><br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/-wJ9OCreddQ/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/-wJ9OCreddQ?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/rAYIaBMxdTw/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/rAYIaBMxdTw?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/bPjs6qyifZk/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/bPjs6qyifZk?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/TgkOHrlq8qg/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/TgkOHrlq8qg?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/lc4F5hejJSw/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/lc4F5hejJSw?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/TgkOHrlq8qg/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/TgkOHrlq8qg?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhartrhari begins his\ngreat treatise, Vakyapadiya, with key-note Verse: The Word Reality (\nSabda-Tatlvam ), without beginning or end, the Immutable Word (akfaram) appears\n(vivartate) as meaning and thing (arthabhavena); thus happens the World-Process\n(prakriya jagato yatah).&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This verse has to be construed in an absolutistic\nsense, &nbsp;as the whole trend and teaching\nof the Vakyapadiya would show.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Pashyanti Vac is\nidentified with the power of intent or will (iccha shakthi) which arises in\nones consciousness; Madhyama Vac which is seated in the intellect (Buddhi) is\nidentified with the power of knowledge (Jnana shakthi); and, Vaikhari Vac where\nthe speaker\u2019s intent gains a bodily- form and expression, and which employs\nbreath and body-organs is identified with the power of action Kriyasakti.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Each of the three\nlevels of speech \u2013 Vac (Pashyanti, Madhyama and Vaikhari) correspond to the\nstructure and content of each of the three chapters (Khanda) of the\nVakyapadiya.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The first Khanda\n(Brahmakanda) which deals mainly with Brahman, the undifferentiated Ultimate\nReality, is said to correspond with Pashyanti Vac.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The second Khanda\n(Vakyakanda) which elaborates on Vakya-sphota describes the differentiation as\nalso the unitary meaning of the sentence. The ideas presented here are said to\ncorrespond with the Madhyama vac.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">And, the third Khanda\n(Padakanda) which deals almost entirely with the analysis of words or parts of\nspeech and their differentiation is said to be closely related to the concern\nof the Vaikhari vac.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sphota is discussed in\nthe first kanda of the Vakyapadiya.&nbsp; The\nprocess of&nbsp; language generation goes\nthrough three stages.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Stage 1: &nbsp;&nbsp;''sphota-shabda'': The first stage is in the\nspeaker's mind, where &nbsp;the sentence is\nconceived in an indistinct way, soon after the idea flashes&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;on\nhis mind.&nbsp; In contrast to the actual\nsound, ''dhvani'', the sphota is&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;permanent (indestructible).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Stage 2: &nbsp;''madhyama vAk'': In the second stage the speaker\ndetermines the sentence pattern in a specific sequence.&nbsp; By this stage, the speaker is aware of the\nsound properties and the time sequence&nbsp; and\nthe phonological pattern of the utterance that is about to be &nbsp;articulated. This mental sentence will be\nmapped into actual sound through articulation in the next stage.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Stage 3: ''vaikhari vak'':\nthe actual speech sounds&nbsp; pronounced\nthrough articulation by the speaker; it is this that becomes audible to the\nlistener.&nbsp; May involve variations in\nspeed of articulation: &nbsp;''druta'' fast,\n''madhya'' medial, or ''vilambita'' slow.&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">So Bhartrhari is\nlogically led to the &nbsp;Para Vak or Brahman\n( Sabda-Brahman ) as the Ultimate Reality from which the World has originated.\nHe calls it Sabda-Brahman because the approach to the Highest is made here\nthrough &nbsp;the Word (Sabda) or Analysis of\nLanguage or because it is expressed through the words.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Pashyanti which also\nmeans the visual image of the word, is indivisible and without inner-sequence;\nmeaning that the origin and destination of speech are one.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Madhyama is an\nintellectual process, during which the speaker becomes aware of the word as it\narises and takes form within him; and he grasps it. Madhyama vak is a sequenced\nbut a pre-vocal thought, Here, the sound is nada&nbsp; and is in a wave or a vibratory (spandana)\nform .<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The transition of Shabdabrahman\nfrom the&nbsp; highest level to the form of\naudible sound is described&nbsp; - as\noccurring in four stages technically known as Para, Pashyanti, Madhyama and\nVaikhari. &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Para originated from\nKundalini in Muladhara chakra.&nbsp; It is\ncomprehended only through practices like nididhyisana.&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Pashyanti originates\nfrom svadhisthana chakra in the navel region. &nbsp;It is attainable only by Yogins.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">These two constitute\nSuksmasphota. ..&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Madhyama&nbsp; originates\nfrom Anahata chakra in the region of the heart&nbsp;\nwhere the voice of the silence is heard. It is also to&nbsp; be called antarasphota. It is to be grasped\nby the &nbsp;&nbsp;intellect and audible only to\none's own innate powers&nbsp; of hearing.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The last one, Vaikhari\noriginates in&nbsp; Vishuddha chakra in the\nregion of the throat and manifests&nbsp; as\nBahyasphota capable of being heard by others. It is&nbsp; because of the nexus that one places oneself in\ntune&nbsp; with the infinite Sphota through\nVaikhari..&nbsp;&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhartrhari subscribes\nto the principle that wherever &nbsp;there are\ndifferences and distinctions, there is a basic unity &nbsp;underlying these differences, for otherwise\nthese differences could not be related and will fall asunder.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot;
