, &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Each difference could\nbecome a radical monad; we cannot even assert there are other monads, for this\nrequires a relation and unification, which &nbsp;mona'dism utterly denies.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Although he first hears\na series of sounds, he&nbsp; ultimately\nperceives the utterance as a unity\u2014the same sphota with which the&nbsp; speaker began .&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The sphota, or meaning-whole,\nthus has two sides to it: the word-sound (dhvani) and the word-meaning (artha).\n&nbsp;&nbsp;Sound and meaning are&nbsp; two aspects residing within the unitary\nsphota, which, according to Bhartrihari,&nbsp;\nis eternal and inherent in consciousness .&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Thus, meaning is not conveyed&nbsp; \u201cfrom the speaker to the hearer\u201d; rather,\n\u201cspoken words serve only as a stimulus&nbsp; to\nreveal or uncover the meaning which was already present in the mind of the&nbsp; hearer\u201d&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">For Bhartrhari, speaking\nis the essence of consciousness, and the means to all knowledge. By speaking,\nlanguage or thought, what is meant is the conveyance of meaning \u2013 thinking does\nnot refer to concept formation, the drawing of inferences, etc. which exist at\nthe two lowest levels (vaikhari and madhyama) only.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Speaking, language or\nthought means conveyance of meaning, and meaning is intertwined with\nconsciousness. This realization is possible at all levels of speech from\nmoments of highest perception to simple everyday cognition.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Epistemologically, it\nis a two level theory as applied to linguistic cognition. The Sphota is a\nnecessary intermediary and is called the Madhyama vak as distinct from\nempirical speech called vaikhari vak.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">These two belong to different orders \u2013\none is empirical and the other is submerged and hidden and therefore has to be\nexcited and manifested by the overt sounds.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The relation between them is that\nof the soul and body, is one of identification or superimposition\u2026that they\n(word and meaning) stand related and are generally identified implies that they\nboth spring from some common source which is the ground of their being\u2026.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Indian philosophers of language are not\ncontent to stop at any duality, the duality of Word and Meaning or the duality\nof Thought and Reality. &nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">As Bhartrhari\nstates it: \"All difference presupposes a unity\"; where there is a\nduality there is an identity pervading it. Otherwise one cannot be related to\nthe other; each would constitute a world by itself</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The transformation of a\nthought into spoken-words involves two kinds of efforts: the internal process\n(abhyantara prayatna) and the external effort (bahya prayatna).<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"></span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhartrhari says that\nSphota is both external (bahya) and internal (abhayantara). And again, in\nunderstanding Sphota as an external entity we have to understand it in the form\nof universal (Jati) and individual or specific (Vyakti).&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">According to\nBhartrhari, Sphota is an auditory image of the sentence.&nbsp; It is indivisible and without inner-sequence.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When an object\nenergy-form, the tanmatra, [objective energy forms- optical-light (eye), mechanical\n(ear) -sound chemical (nose and tongue), mechanical, thermal (skin) a vishaya\n(cognized object) - ] is sensed through antahkaranas, this verb state becomes a\nstate of sentence \u2013 bhava or thought.&nbsp;\nThis state is known as madhyama mode of language -the vibhakti state of\nsentence or thought and is the modulated sphota (undergone vivartanam \u2013\nreversible change). <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This modulated energy-\nform gets transformed into sound energy through vocal chords\u2019 movement and is\nexpressed /uttered. This is the vaikhari mode of language. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">All this happens in the\nspeaker/teacher. This uttered sound-energy (the vaikhari mode of language) is\npicked up by the ears (sense organs) of the listener/learner and becomes\nsentence in the madhyama mode- the modulated sphota mode in conjugation with\nthe antahkaranas (inner mental tools).&nbsp;</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This sentence-energy\nform in madhyama mode is in subject-verb-object (the triad-triputi) form. This\nmode of language gets demodulated (reverse transformation of sphota - the\nvivartanam in the reverse direction) into meaning, resulting in\nunderstanding/experience in the pasyanti mode- to a verb (sense), in present\ncontinuous or infinite form, the subject and object being dissolved in the\nsense of uttered /expressed sound.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nada is not a part of\ndhvani (external sound).&nbsp; Rather dhvani\ninstead arises as a projection of nada. Rather dhvani instead arises as a\nprojection of nada.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The term \"sphota\"&nbsp; of Bhartrihari ( 7000 BC )&nbsp; is used by Panini's ( 5500&nbsp; BC)&nbsp; as\n\u201csphot\u00e2yana\u201d in his treatise Asht\u00e2dhy\u00e2y\u00ee, however it was Patanjali&nbsp; ( 5000 BC ) who explicitly discusses sphota\nin his Mah\u00e2bh\u00e2shya.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sphota has two parts,\ninternal and external, both important, and reliant on one another. One is the\nsound which the meaning is carried in (dhvani), and the other is the actual\nmeaning that the sound carries (varna).&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Mantras are related to the sphota\ntheory because of the mystic origins of the mantras. There is an assumption that\nmantras are language because many are often a recitation of Vedic texts, but\nthat does not mean that they are all language<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Patanjali&nbsp;&nbsp; says that dhvani is heard by the ear and\nsphota is grasped by intellect. Therefore, both sphota and dhvani are essential\nfor the knowledge of meaning . Patanjali mentions that language (shabda) has\ntwo aspects, namely, sphota and dhvani.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The former is the permanent unchanging\nelement, whereas the latter refers to the non-permanent element of the speech\nassociated with length, tempo, and various peculiarities of any individual\nspeaker. Therefore, dhvani is the actualized and ephemeral (lasting a very\nshort time, or transient) element and an attribute of the former..&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Patanjali\npoints out that the sphota, which is revealed by the articulate sounds, can be\npresented through phonemes only. A phoneme (vowel) which represents sphoTa\nremains the same in three modes of utterance, i.e. slow, fast and faster,\nwhereas dhvani (articulate sound) differs in different utterances.. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">According to Patanjali,\nsphota is a conceptual entity or generic feature of articulated sounds, either\nin the form of isolated phonemes or a series of phonemes. It is a permanent\nelement of physical sounds which are transitory in nature, and which vary in\nlength, tempo and pitch of the speaker. It is an actualized replica of\neuphemeral sounds.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">. For Patanjali, Sphota\nrefers to the constant element in the auditory image of the varied articulated\nsounds&nbsp; whereas the term dhvani refers to\nthe physical articulated sounds, which is associated with length,&nbsp; tempo and various peculiarities of the\nindividual speaker.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Patanjali says that sphota\nis permanent element in the word, and is the essence of it; while Dhvani \u2013 the\nuttered sound \u2013 is an fleeting element, and is only an aspect of Sphota. For\nPatanjali, Sphota may be a singular letter or a fixed pattern of letters.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">He\nconcludes that Sphota is permanent , unchanging and is manifested by the\nchanging sounds (Dhvani ) uttered by the speaker and heard by the listener.. The\nnoisy element (dhvani, audible part) can be long or short, but the sphota\nremains unaffected by individual speaker differences.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The grammarians accept\nSphota as a single&nbsp; meaningful entity. It\nis permanent and unchanging,&nbsp; and is\nmanifested by the ephemeral dhvanis, uttered&nbsp;\nby the speaker and heard by the listener.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sphota which is mental\nimpression of an audible sound pattern, is the cause of that sound pattern.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The sphota perceived by\nthe listener is not different from dhvani produced by the speaker. In this\ncontext, sphotta means auditorily perceived sound, as there is no gap between\nthe perception of sphota and dhvani. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Dhvani refers to the\nsounds emitted from the speaker's vocal organ, whereas the sounds reaching the\nears of the listener is called sphota. Here, the relation between sphota and\ndhvani is that of manifester and manifested. &nbsp;&nbsp;Sphota represents the constant distinctive\nphonetic features revealed to the listener's ear, whereas dhvani represents the\ngross sound. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sphota is a replica of\ndhvani having phonetic features. That's why it is an \"auditory image of\nthe sound\" .&nbsp; Sphota is indivisible\nin itself. It expresses itself in its&nbsp; dyal\nform of word and meaning.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sphota and ..dhvani are\ntwo aspects of a&nbsp;word.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sphota is the\npermanent element in the word.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">It may be considered\nthe essential word. Dhvani is</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">the\nactualised and ephemeral element in the word. It</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">is considered as an attribute of Sphota.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">SPHOTA CANNOT BE\nDIVORCED FROM THE SOUND<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Dhvani has absolute\nvowel length and individual peculiarities.&nbsp;\nIt depends on the individuality of the speaker and the&nbsp; effort with which the words are uttered. Sphota\nis permanent and unchanging and is manifested by the&nbsp; ephemeral dhvanis uttered by the speaker and\nheard by&nbsp; the listener<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The abstract sound\npattern with the time-sequence&nbsp; is called\nPrakrtadhvani. It is the external aspect &nbsp;of the language. The internal aspect of the language\nis Sphota and is directly attached to the meaning<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sphota represents both\nartha and dhvani, &nbsp;artha refer to the\nconcept of meaning and dhvani refer to the uttered sound.&nbsp; The linguistic whole or the sign or sphota\nhas an inherent force towards&nbsp; manifestation\nthat produce the signifier and signified; or artha and dhvani. &nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Both&nbsp; sign\nand sphota&nbsp; are rooted with in language,\nthat works through spacing, punctuation, differentiation in time and space.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">On the basis of\nPatanjali\u2019s explanation, Sphota is both internal and external. The internal\nform of Sphota is the innate essence of the word \u2013meaning. The external aspect\nof Sphota is the uttered sound which is perceived by the sense organs.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">It\nmerely serves to manifest the inner Sphota with its inherent word-meaning. Dhvani\nis the auditory aspect of the Sabda.&nbsp; The\nintellect of the listener grasps Dhvani as in a flash, Sphota.&nbsp; The Sphota is therefore the intellectual,\nsubtle and inaudible aspect of the Sabda.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Patanjali explains, the word ghtata consists\nletters/syllables gh, a, t and a, uttered in a sequence. The letters as heard\nare Dhvani . Immediately after the last letter is uttered the whole (akhanda),\nindivisible (not sequential) sense bursts forth in a flash Sphota.&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Dhvani is a divisible\nentity. It is produced and grasped in a particular sequence and generally by\nmistake the same qualities of sound are superimposed on sphota<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">According to\nBhartrhari, the physical audible sound manifests the sphota, which is nothing\nbut the mental articulated image of the sound through which the meaning is\nconveyed to the listener. Thus, dhvani is the physical body of the word,\nwhereas sphota is the conceptual entity of sound.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">According to Bhartrhari,\nsphota is an auditory image of sound. It is indivisible and without\ninner-sequence. It does not stand for the meaning-bearing aspect of the word.\nIt is not over and above the sound. Sphota merely represents the class of\nindividual sounds, whereas dhvani represents a particular sound.&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhartahari employed the\nterm Sphota to indicate the whole, Artha to refer to the concept or meaning and\nDhvani to refer to the uttered and heard sound. &nbsp;&nbsp;Bhartrhari makes a distinction between Sabda\nand Dhvani. The former is the \u2018Real word\u2019; while the latter is the \u2018sound\u2019\nproduced by the speaker in order to give expression to Sabda.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhartrhari describes\nword, the ever-present principle, as a selfluminous&nbsp; identity &nbsp;Svaprakasachaitanya), &nbsp;sphota or word reveals itself as well as&nbsp; the object that comes into contact with it,\nwhen the sphota reveals itself, it&nbsp; reveals\nthe sound (Dhvani) also, but we confuse word with sound.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The change in speed or\naccent or mode of uttering a word (vritti) does not alter its Sabda or Sphota.\nThe physical aspect of the word that is the quality of its sound (Dhvani) might\nvary but its Sphota remains unchanged. Thus, in effect Sabda too remains\nunchanged. Again, Dhvani the physical form of the sound could be articulate\n(like human voice) or inarticulate (like sounds of animals, drums etc.)&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nevertheless, the intellect perceives that\nDhvani in a flash (Sphota) depending on the listener\u2019s experience (anubhava),\nreasoning (yukthi) and authority of scriptures (Sastras and Grammar).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In Sanskrit Grammar\nSabda stands for the word manifested by Dhvani, the articulated sound. While Dhvani\nis variable, Sabda is not.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The purpose of the Dhvani is to give expression to\nand to act as a vehicle for Vak. The Dhvani as perceived by the intellect of\nthe speaker in a flash is Sphota. The Sphota is the intellectual impression of\nthe audible sound patterns. The Sabda therefore combines in itself the physical\nform (dhvani) of word and its intellectual inaudible from (Sphota).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Music is a painting on\nthe canvas of silence. If every sound on this cosmos and planet earth were\nsimultaneously recorded, there would be only one single sound OM.&nbsp;&nbsp; Nada is not a part of dhvani (external\nsound).&nbsp; Rather dhvani instead arises as\na projection of nada.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The purpose of the Dhvani,\nthe articulated sound, is to give expression to, and to act as a vehicle for\nSabda which is the intent of the speaker. One\u2019s mode of speaking, accent,\nstress and speed etc (Dhvani) might vary; but, the speech-content or intention\n(Sabda) remains unaltered. Thus, while Dhvani is variable; Sabda, the\nunderlying cause of the Dhvani, is not.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhartrhari &nbsp;classifies Dhvani into two sorts \u2013 Prakrta\nDhvani and Vaikrta Dhvani \u2013 (primary or natural sounds and derived or\ntransformed sounds). Bhartrhari applies various technical terms like \u2018sabda\u2019 or\n\u2018sphota\u2019, \u2018dhvani\u2019 and \u2018nada\u2019. Bhartrhari refers to \u2018sabda\u2019 or \u2018sphota\u2019 that\nthe inner unity which conveys the&nbsp; meaning.\nThe original source concept of sphota has come from the Vedic time of Indian\nthought.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhartrhari states that\nsphota and dhvani are&nbsp; roducing\nsimultaneously. This theory conceives that there is no gap at all in the yield\nof both. The sphota is the&nbsp; flame of fire\nand is the central part of sound. But the dhvani is the light of the flame.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">On\ncertain occasions we see the light without seeing the flame. Likewise we hear\ndhvani without experiencing sphota. As the flame and light are&nbsp; produced at the same time so is the output of\nthe sphota and the dhvani.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhartirhari uses the\nword sphota in the sense of the meaning bearer or expressive word, a concept\ndifferent from the actual articulated sound which is called dhvani.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">According to Patanjali,\nsphota is not identical with shabda. It is rather a permanent element of\nshabda, whereas dhvani represents its non-permanent aspect. The sphota is not\naudible like dhvani . It is manifested by the articulated sounds. The dhvani\nelement of speech may differ in phonetic value with reference to the variation\nin the utterance of different speakers.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Differences in speed of utterance and\ntime distinctions are attributes of dhvani, which can not affect the nature of\nsphota revealed by the sound. When a sound passes from a speaker's lips, sphota\nis revealed instantaneously. But before the listener comprehends anything, dhvani\nelements manifest the permanent element of shabda.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">So, sphota comes first and\nmanifesting dhvani also continues to exist after the revelation of sphota. That\nis why Patanjali remarks that dhvani-s are actualized and euphemeral elements\nand attributes of sphota<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sphota, Patanjali says,\nis a permanent element in the word; and, in fact is the essence of the word.\nThe permanent unchanging Sphota is manifested by changing sounds (Dhvani).\nHere, Dhvani is the uttered sound heard by the listener; and, is but an aspect\nof Sphota.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Thus, according to Patanjali, Sphota has an internal and an external\naspect. The inner aspect is the innate expression of the word-meaning; while\nthe external aspect is a vehicle to manifest the internal aspect; and is\nperceived by the sense organs of the listener.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The permanence of\nsphota (as opposed to the destructibility of dhvani), is based on Bhartrihari's\ntheory of vivarta which is the very foundation of&nbsp; his shabdatattva.&nbsp; vivarta is defined as \"the assumption of\none thing as&nbsp; some thing else without\nloosing its inherent nature (tattva) through apparent diversity of different\nunreal forms<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The term dhvani (sound)\nis derived from the root 'dhvan' to make sound. Dhvani is an older term going\nback to Atharva Veda, where it was used in the sense of sound, tune, noise etc.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhartrhari\ndistinguishes between the word itself (sometimes called sphota) and the sounds\nthat manifest it. These sounds themselves are subdivided in one passage of the\nVakyapadiya into prakrta dhvani and vaikrta dhvani. &nbsp;&nbsp;Sphota, according to Bhartrhari, is always\nintimately related to dhvani. As soon as the sounds are produced the sphota is\ncognized instantly. Thus, sounds are manifesters and sphot is manifested<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhartrhari\ndistinguishes between (1) the sphot a of an expression, which denotes the\nexpression as a single unit conveying a meaning; (2) the prakrta-dhvani of an\nexpression, i.e. the phonological structure assigned to the type it represents;\nand (3) the vaikrta-dhvani, i.e. the phonetic realization in its particular\nutterance-token.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">First, we have the\nactual sounds of the words uttered; this is the vaikrta-dhvani. These sounds\nreveal the permanent prakrta-dhvani which is an abstraction from the vari-ous\nvaikrta-dhvani-s, or which may be considered as the linguistically normal form\ndevoid of the personal variations which are linguistically relevant.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">For the listener this\nentire process is reversed, and results in the&nbsp;\nmanifestation of the indivisible sphota-shabda from the divisible\ndhvani.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Dhvani is the essence\nor soul of poetry. . The poet has to be inspired, charged with emotion to\ncreate a poetry that comes alive with suggestions (Dhvani). The poet is the\nfirst reader of his Kavya; and the first one to experience Rasa from its Dhvani\nsensitivities<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Dhvani principle can be\nsaid, briefly, in statements: Rasa (aesthetic experience) is the soul of\npoetry; the mode in which the body of the poetry reveals it is Dhvani\n(suggestion); and, the harmonious accordance of the body and the soul is\nAuchitya (propriety) . Rasa, Dhvani and Auchitya are the Prastha traya, the\nthree fundamental principles of Kavya Shastra.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhartrhari explicates\nthat dhvani has two faces viz. \u2018prakrtadhvani\u2019 and \u2018vaikrtadhvani\u2019.\nPrakrtadhvani is the original sound, which is the cause of sphota. But\nvaikrtadhvani is the pure phonetic term used by grammarians. It is the sound\nspoken by the speaker and heard by the listener. There is no partition of time\nin the sphota whereas there is interpolation of time in the reflections of this\ngist.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">According to him,\nsphota signifies the audible sound or dhvani. Sphota controls within the\nUniversal sounds whereas dhvani within a specific sound. In modern conditions\nsphota can be understood as having ceaseless typical&nbsp; phonetic characteristics. But dhvani is of a\nphonic type.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sphota is that which is to be demonstrated and dhvani is demonstrating.\nDhvani may be variable considering on the speakers style of vocalization. But\nsphota as the unit of&nbsp; speech is not\ncapable to such fluctuations. Bhartrhari formulates the idea of sphota is a\nunique philosophical proportion. For him, sphota is neither a meaning abiding\nunit nor a linguistic mark.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sphota is the real cause\nof the Cosmos. Bhartrhari\u2019s theory of sphota is also known as \u2018sabdadvaita\u2019 or\n\u2018sabdatattva\u2019. He reveals this&nbsp; with\nmention to five aids to sensible knowledge, viz. pratyaksa (perception),\nanumana (inference), agama (sabda),&nbsp; abhyasa\n(repetition) and adrsta (invisible) .</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;At the personal level, Sphota is the idea\nwhich twinkles on the mind&nbsp; when a sound\nis expressed. At the universal level, Sphota is the force behind the\nWord-Logos, the eternal declaring&nbsp; itself\nthrough sound. The absolute potentiality of the occurrence of life is charted\nin the sound of \u2018Aum\u2019, the&nbsp; pranava, that\ndirect prana or breath.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The \u2018Mandukyopanisad\u2019\nassorts the whole enigma of Brahmn into an elementary sound Aum, the three\nconditions of&nbsp; waking, dreaming and deep\nsleep allied to the three mantras of A, U and M, the Sphota, the Nada-Sabda\nBrahman&nbsp; being the \"material of all\nwords\".<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhartrhari depicts that\nsphota is a monistic philosophy pertaining the fundamental trouble of the word\nand its&nbsp; meaning. He distinguishes two\ncomponents in each important word, the component of sound (sabda) and the&nbsp; component of meaning (artha).&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The sphota is\nan inseparable meaning assuming unit of a word, which blushes on the&nbsp; mind when a sound is expressed. It is the\nsublime theoretical and transcendental speech effect. In the Veda\u2019s, there&nbsp; are many expressions which prove that the\nconcept of sphota has developed in Veda\u2019s. Rig-Veda says that a\u201d mahan&nbsp; devah sabdah\u201d, which means the Great God, is\nspeech itself.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Since Sphota assumes that\nthe apparent Universe arose out of an exploding forth from the changeless\nsubstratum. It&nbsp; is also seen as the\npremature \u2018Big Bang\u2019 theory of the Universe, retroflexed in each individual\nmind as the possible &nbsp;arousing of\nawareness through words and language.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sphotavada says that the very inwardness\nof the Universe is&nbsp; Sphota. The sound of\nspeech (dhvani) apparently arouses the Sphota in the listener as varnasphota, &nbsp;padasphota,&nbsp;\nand vakyasphota, the phoneme-in-morpheme-diction-knowledge, the\nword-diction-knowledge, and the text-diction knowledge,&nbsp; individually.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">According to Bhartrhari, the\nmeaning is accomplished through vakyasphota only. Even&nbsp; today this theory is widely admits among\nmodern linguists as the most arrant analysis into the deepness of language, making\nappreciable profoundness to the Philosophy of Language, Linguistics, and\nespecially in Semiotics.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">For Bhartrhari the two aspects\nof word-sound ( dhvani ) and the word-meaning&nbsp;\n(artha), differentiated in the mind and yet integrated like two sides of\nthe same coin, constitute the sphota. Bhartrhari emphasizes the meaning-bearing\nor revelatory function of this two-sided &nbsp;unity, the sphota , which he maintains is\neternal and inherent &nbsp;in consciousness<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">An important feature of\nsound is its fixed capacity to express a particular phoneme. For instance, a\nparticular sound, produced by its particular articulated efforts, reveals a\nparticular phoneme <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The sound-wave\nemanating from its origin is compared to a light-wave starting from the\noriginal flame. Once the first flame has been produced by the fire-producing\nmachinery, the light-wave continues to spread in all direction, even after the\nfire-producing machinery has stopped <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The sound, which\ncontains longitudinal vibration in it, travels in all directions. The range\ncovered by the sound depends upon loudness (intensity) of the sound. The area\ncovered by the sound may be smaller or larger, but that does not change the\nduration of the sphota <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sphota is the first\nsound. It results from the conjunction and disjunction of the vocal organs with\npoints of articulations. On the other hand, sounds, which originate from the\nfirst sound and spread in all directions and travel over a certain range, are\nthe dhvanis. In short, the articulated sound is sphota, and its continuation in\nthe form of sound -waves is called dhvani <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhartrhari makes a new\ndistinction within the manifesting sounds: primary sound (praakruta dhvani) and\nsecondary sound (vaikruta dhvani) <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Primary sounds are\nthose, without which the form of sphota would remain unmanifested and therefore\nunperceived . Primary sounds are considered to be the root cause of sphota,\nbecause, as soon as we hear the primary sounds, sphota is perceived. Due to\nthis close relationship between the two, the features of primary sounds are\noften attributed to the sphota.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">According to\nBhartrihari sphota signifies spoken language, with the audible sound (dhvani)\nas its special quality. In Bhartrihari\u2019s treatment of this concept, while the\naudible noise may vary depending on the speaker\u2019s mode of utterance, sphota as\nthe meaning unit of speech is not subject to such variations.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This is so\nbecause for Bhartrihari, meaning is conveyed by the sentence. To explicate this\ntheory, Bhartrihari depends on the root of sphota, namely sphut, meaning \u201cto\nburst forth\u2026\u201d as in the \u201cidea that spews forth\u201d (in an internal mental state)\nwhen a meaningful sound, the sentence as a whole, is uttered.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sphota is the cause of\nmanifested language, which is meant to convey meaning. Sphota is more\nspecifically identified as the underlying totality of linguistic capability, or\n\"potency\" and secondarily as the cause of two differentiated aspects\nof manifested meaning: applied meaning expressed as dhvani, the audible sound\npatterns of speech and artha-language as meaning-bearing.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The\ngrammatical/syntactical parts of the underlying sphota can only be heard and\nunderstood through its phonetic elements. Bhartrihari explains that the\napparent difference between sphota and dhvani arises as we utter words.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Initially, the word exists in the mind of the speaker as a unity but is\nmanifested as a sequence of different sounds-thus giving the appearance of\ndifferentiation. dhvanis may be more specifically described as merely the\naudible possibility of meaning, a necessary but hardly sufficient condition of\nmeaning.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">According to\nBhartrhari,&nbsp; the gross sound pattern,\nDhvani or Nada, is a sequence of sounds. Those sounds are employed to convey or\nto give an audible form to the intent of the speaker.&nbsp; Those audible sounds through their divisions\nand time sequence, produced one after another by the speech organs, act as\nmeans (upaya) or as vehicles to transport the intent of the speaker.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Such\nquanta of sound-sequences (words) might create an impression as though they are\nindependent; and, the meaning intended to be conveyed by them (Sphota)\ncomprises several parts. But, in truth, the individual words have no separate\nexistence; and, both the sentence and its meaning (Sphota) are part-less.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sphota in the ordinary\nconversation, according to Bhartrhari refers to a spontaneous process where a\nlatent idea or thought arising out of the consciousness or the mind of the\nspeaker is manifested by the sounds (Dhvani) of the spoken words employed in\nthe sentence; and, it is directly grasped, through intuition (Prathibha), by\nthe mind (Buddhi) of the listener.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhartrhari explained\nthat, initially, the thought exists in the mind of the speaker as a unity \u2013\nSabda or Sphota \u2013 intending a certain meaning. When uttered, ( in an effort to\nconvey that thought through a sequence of sounds (Dhvani) that follow one after\nthe other) , it produces certain specific sound-patterns (Nada).&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">It might look\nas though the articulated word-sounds are separated in time and space. However,\nthough the word-sounds reach the listener in a sequence, the listener\neventually grasps the completed sentence as a single unit, as its meaning\nbursts forth (Sphota) in a flash of understanding or insight (prathibha).&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The\nsame Sphota which originated in speaker\u2019s mind re-manifests in listener\u2019s mind,\ntransmitting the meaning. Understanding of the meaning must be the immediate\nand intuitive grasp of the sentence as a whole. Thus, while the articulated\nsounds (Dhvani, Nada), apparently having divisions and sequence, are the\nexternal forms; Sphota is the inner unity conveying the meaning.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In modern terms Spho\u1e6da\ncan be understood as having constant distinctive phonetic features, whereas\nDhavni is of a phonic nature. Spho\u1e6da is that which is to be manifested (vya\u1e45gya),\nand the Dhvani is manifesting (vya\u00f1jaka). Spho\u1e6da is not uttered but it is\nperceived by the hearer.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhartrhari draws a line\nof demarcation between two classes of sounds:-- prakrta (original sound) and\nvaikrta sound (derivative transformation).&nbsp;\nWithout the former, the unmanifested sphota cannot be comprehended. The&nbsp; latter enables the manifested sphota to be\ncomprehended for longer and longer&nbsp; moments\nof time without any cessation.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In the levels of\nPhenomenalization of the sabda, the first stage is called&nbsp; sphota in pasyanthi stage and the second and\nthird stages are collectively&nbsp; called\nnada or dhvani. Sphota is the underlying cause of the dhvani.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The dhvani&nbsp; in the second stage gets the distinction of\nshort (hwasa) long (dirga) and extralong&nbsp;\n(pluta) and it is called prakrta dhvani. The same dhvani in the third\nstage&nbsp; gets the differentiation of\nrapidity (druta) medium (madhyamam) and slowness&nbsp; (vilambita) and it is called vaikrta dhvani.\nThese two levels of dhvani&nbsp; correspond to\nthe madhyama and vaikhari.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In the first two levels of the sabda,&nbsp; the dhvani is known as madhyamavak and in the\nlast step or in the state of pronunciation or utterance of the word, it is\nknown as vaikrtavak the vaikrta &nbsp;dhvani.\nVaikrta vak is transitory in contradistinction to the prakrtauak.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">According to Bhartrhari\nsphota signifies the audible sound or dhvani. Sphota controls within the\nUniversal sounds whereas dhvani within a specific sound. In modern conditions\nsphota can be understood as having ceaseless typical&nbsp; phonetic characteristics.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">But dhvani is of a\nphonic type. Sphota is that which is to be demonstrated and dhvani is&nbsp; demonstrating. Dhvani may be variable\nconsidering on the speakers style of vocalization.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">But sphota as the unit of speech\nis not capable to such fluctuations. Bhartrhari formulates the idea of sphota\nis a unique philosophical proportion. For him, sphota is neither a meaning\nabiding unit nor a linguistic mark.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Indian grammarians\naccept the four speech situations namely para, pasyanti, madhyama and vaikhari.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Since Sphota assumes\nthat the apparent Universe arose out of an exploding forth from the changeless\nsubstratum. It&nbsp; is also seen as the\npremature \u2018Big Bang\u2019 theory of the Universe, retroflexed in each individual\nmind as the possible &nbsp;arousing of\nawareness through words and language.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Sphotavada says that the very inwardness\nof the Universe is&nbsp; Sphota. The sound of\nspeech (dhvani) apparently arouses the Sphota in the listener as varnasphota,\npadasphota,&nbsp; nd vakyasphota, the\nphoneme-in-morpheme-diction-knowledge, the word-diction-knowledge, and the\ntext-diction knowledge,&nbsp; individually.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">According to Bhartrhari, the meaning is accomplished through vakyasphota only.\nEven&nbsp; today this theory is widely admits\namong modern linguists as the most arrant analysis into the deepness of\nlanguage,&nbsp; making appreciable\nprofoundness to the Philosophy of Language, Linguistics, and especially in\nSemiotics.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The basic principle of\ndhvani is innate in sphota vada;&nbsp; strictly\nspeaking it is not admissible to take words separately by splitting a sentence.\nTo those who advocated&nbsp; the divisibility\nof both pada (word) and vakya (sentence) it&nbsp;\nis the last sentence in a structure that indicates sphota.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sphota is practically\nmanifest from tha last sound. It is&nbsp; from\nthe last sound that the cognition of the entire word structure&nbsp; is derived, together with the impression\nproduced&nbsp; by preceding sound. Sphotu in\nthis context is 'antima&nbsp; buddhi graahya'\nor what is known by the last word, sphota &nbsp;is also 'antima varna graahya' , or what is\nknown by the last syllable as even the last alphabet.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Indian rhetoricians\nhave made a meticulous study of&nbsp; both the\nmeaning and emotive context of words. Words have&nbsp; at least two meanings, one literal meaning,\nthe other&nbsp; suggested meaning which is\ndescribed as 'dhvani' or the&nbsp; meaning\nthat echoes (the literaral meaning of sphota is&nbsp;\n'burst out' or the energy released when something is&nbsp; broken). Sphota is a distinct entity, by\nitself. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Dhvani is so termed\nbecause it sounds, rings, or&nbsp; reverbrates\nbecause it is sphota. The idea of one thing&nbsp;\nindicating something else which it is not is the&nbsp; distinguishing character of dhvani. In a\nverbal expression&nbsp; 'abhidha' and 'lak~na'\nform the nature of the condition and &nbsp;'vyanjakn'\nor 'dhvani' is of nature of contents.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The sequence is from\nsound to word, and from word to sphota&nbsp; and\nfrom sphota to meaning.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhartrhari's concept of\nSabda and dhvani has definitely a metaphysical out look which helped him to\nconstruct a 'Grand Narrative' of language.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhartrhari employs\nthree technical terms: sabda/sphota, dhvani, and nada. By sabda and or sphota\nhe refers to the inner unity which conveys the meaning. The dhvanis are\ndescribed as imperceptible particles which, become gross and perceptible sounds\nand are called nada.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">These nada function to suggest the word, sphota or sabda.\nAnd since these nadas which are gross and audible, have division and sequence,\nthe word also has parts, when in reality it is changeless and sequenceless.\nBhartrhari offers the example of reflection in water.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Just as an object\nreflected in the water may seem to have movement because of the movement of the\nwater, similarly the word, or sphota, takes on the properties of uttered speech\n(sequence, loudness or softness, accent, etc.) in which it is manifested\u2026why is\nthe unity expressed in the diversity called speech?&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In Bhartrhari's view, it is\nbecause the spota itself contains an inner energy (kartu) that seeks to burst\nforth into expression. What appears to be unitary is thus seen to contain all\nthe potentialities of multiplicity and complexity like the seed and the sprout\nor the egg and the chicken. In the Vakyapadiya, Bhartrhari suggests two ways in\nwhich the energy of speech causes the phenomenalization of the sphota.
